## Preface

The  EGOV-CeDEM-ePart  2025  conference,  for  short  EGOV  2025,  was  organized  by the  IFIP  WG  8.5  Information  Systems  in  Public  Administration.  The  conference  is  dedicated  to  digital  or  electronic  government,  open  government,  local  government  (smart cities), smart governance, artificial intelligence (AI), e-democracy, policy informatics,  and  electronic  participation.  With  a  long  tradition  along  its  various  branches,  the EGOV-CeDEM-ePart  conference  has  gained  its  reputation  of  being  the  key  and  leading conference  worldwide  in  the  research  domains  of  digital/electronic,  open,  and  smart government,  as  well  as  electronic  participation.

The  call  for  papers  attracted  completed  research  papers,  work-in-progress  papers on ongoing  research (including doctoral papers), posters, as well as  workshops  and practitioner  papers.  This  volume  contains  only  full  research  papers.  All  submissions were  assessed  through  a  double-blind  peer-review  process,  with  at  least  three  reviewers per  submission,  and  48  papers  were  accepted  from  116  submissions  (an  acceptance  rate of  41%).  The  submitted  papers  were  of  high  quality,  and  many  reviewers  indicated  that the  topics  of  the  papers  they  reviewed  were  novel.

The  review  process  was  based  on  a  double-blind  reviewing  process  and  conflicts of  interest  were  actively  avoided.  Authors  of  papers  submitted  their  papers  to  a  track. The  track  chairs  had  access  only  to  the  papers  within  their  own  track  and  could  assign reviewers  and  propose  acceptance  decisions.  The  lead  track  chairs  were  editors  of  the proceedings,  in  addition  to  the  general  chairs.  Track  chairs  were  not  allowed  to  submit  to their  own  track,  nor  were  their  close  collaborators,  to  avoid  any  conflict  of  interest.  Track chairs  could  either  submit  to  another  track  or  to  the  'track  chairs'  track.  The  latter  was handled  by  one  of  the  general  chairs,  and  these  submissions  were  reviewed  in  the  same way  as  all  other  submissions.  The  general  chairs  checked  after  the  submission  deadline whether  there  was  any  conflict  of  interest  among  the  papers  submitted  to  tracks,  and  if so,  the  respective  paper  was  moved  to  another  track.  The  track  chairs  checked  that  all papers  were  submitted  anonymously.  If  not,  the  authors  were  asked  to  resubmit  within  a couple  of  days.  Track  chairs  assigned  the  reviewers  and  selected  the  program  committee members  in  such  a  way  that  experts  in  each  area  reviewed  the  papers  and  there  were  no conflicts  of  interest.  After  at  least  three  reviews  were  received,  the  track  chairs  made  a proposal  for  a  decision  per  paper.  The  decisions  were  discussed  in  a  meeting  with  the general  and  track  chairs  to  ensure  that  the  decisions  were  made  in  a  consistent  manner across  tracks.

Among  the  full  research  paper  submissions,  21  papers  (empirical  and  conceptual) were  accepted  for  this  year's  Springer  LNCS  ePart  proceedings  (vol.  15978).  This  volume includes  papers  distributed  over  the  following  tracks:

- General  eDemocracy  &amp;  eParticipation
- Governance,  Digital  Legislation,  and  Policy
- Digital  Technologies  and  Sustainable  Development
- Managing  e-Government  Projects

## · Digital  Society

Artificial  Intelligence  Governance  and  its  Societal  Challenges

As  in  the  previous  years  and  per  the  recommendation  of  the  Paper  Awards  Committee,  under  the  leadership  of  Manuel  Pedro  Rodríguez  Bolívar  from  the  University  of Granada,  Spain,  and  Noella  Edelmann  from  the  University  for  Continuing  Education Krems,  Austria,  the  IFIP  EGOV-CeDEM-ePart  2025  conference  granted  outstanding paper  awards  in  three  distinct  categories:

- The  most  innovative  research  contribution
- The  most  promising  practical  concept
- The  most  compelling  critical  research  reflection

The  winners  in  each  category  were  announced  during  the  awards  ceremony  at  the conference.

The  IFIP  EGOV  2025  conference  was  hosted  in  Austria,  at  the  University  for  Continuing  Education  Krems.  The  conference  sessions  were  hosted  2-4  September  at  the University  for  Continuing  Education  Krems'  Campus.  The  University  for  Continuing Education  Krems  is  Europe's  leading  public  university  dedicated  to  continuing  education,  combining  teaching  excellence  with  cutting-edge  research  to  address  key  societal challenges.  Located  in  the  vibrant  and  historic  city  of  Krems  an  der  Donau,  the  university thrives  within  a  rich  academic  and  cultural  environment,  surrounded  by  the  charm  and legacy  of  one  of  Austria's  oldest  cities.  As  part  of  the  conference,  the  PhD  colloquium and  the  Junior  Faculty  School  were  hosted  at  Göttweig  Abbey,  a  historic  Benedictine monastery  situated  atop  a  hill  in  Austria's  Wachau  Valley.  Known  for  its  impressive baroque  architecture,  Göttweig  Abbey  offers  a  setting  that  blends  historical  significance with  a  peaceful  atmosphere,  ideal  for  focused  academic  discussions.  With  origins  dating  back  to  the  eleventh  century,  the  monastery  provided  a  unique  context  for  scholarly exchange.  The  PhD  Colloquium  was  a  full-day  event  on  31  August,  open  only  to  those who  were  admitted,  and  offered  a  limited  number  of  PhD  bursaries.  The  Junior  Faculty School  was  a  full-day  event  on  1  September,  for  sharing  experiences  to  advance  the career  of  young  researchers  interested  in  digitalization  and  government.

Many  people  behind  the  scenes  make  large  events  like  this  conference  happen.  We would  like  to  thank  the  members  of  the  Program  Committee,  the  reviewers,  and  the  track chairs  for  their  great  efforts  in  reviewing  the  submitted  papers.  We  would  also  like  to express  our  deep  gratitude  to  Peter  Parycek,  Gabriela  Viale  Pereira,  and  their  local  team at  the  University  for  Continuing  Education  Krems  for  hosting  the  conference.

The  papers  in  these  proceedings  range  from  societal  to  scientific,  and  from  rigorous to  innovative.  We  hope  you  enjoy  reading  them!

September  2025

## Foundations  and  Frameworks of  eParticipation

<!-- image -->

## Conceptualizing  Inclusive  eParticipation. A  Systematic  Literature  Review

<!-- image -->

Ursula  Sokolaj 1( B ) ,  Casandra  Grundstrom 1 ,  and  Silvia  Masiero 2

- 1 Department  of  Computer  Science,  NTNU,  Trondheim,  Norway

ursula.sokolaj@ntnu.no

- 2 Department  of  Informatics,  University  of  Oslo,  Oslo,  Norway

Abstract. The  widespread  use  of  ICT  and  the  internet  has  compelled  governments  worldwide  to  rethink  how  they  engage  in  dialogue  with  citizens.  These technology-mediated  interactions  have  given  rise  to  eParticipation,  a  concept  with significant  potential  to  address  democratic  deficits.  However,  ensuring  meaningful  and  inclusive  participation  requires  that  all  citizens  have  equal  opportunities to  engage  while  barriers  faced  by  disadvantaged  groups  are  actively  addressed. This  systematic  literature  review  conceptualizes  the  dimensions  for  inclusive  eParticipation,  through  27  included  articles  from  across  5  databases.  19  dimensions have  been  identified  within  6  concepts  for  inclusion  in  digital  participation - accessibility,  knowledge,  motivation,  safety,  impact,  and  empowerment.  We  propose  a new  conceptual  framework  from  these  findings,  which  can  guide  efforts  towards understanding  and  enhancing  inclusion  in  digital  democratic  engagement.

Keywords: eParticipation · inclusion · systematic  literature  review

## 1 Introduction

The  pervasive  use  of  Information  and  Communication  Technology  (ICT)  and  the  internet infrastructure  has  forced  governments  all  over  the  world  to  redefine  the  way  they  engage in  dialogue  with  citizens.  Today,  over  80%  of  United  Nations  Member  States  utilize  their potential  for  public  governance  [1].  Citizen  participation  in  decision-making  processes  is a  core  principle  of  democracy  [2],  and  the  integration  of  technology  into  these  interactions has  given  rise  to  the  concept  of  electronic  participation,  or  eParticipation.  According  to the  UN  [3],  eParticipation  is  essential  for  better  access  to  information  and  public  services, while  allowing  citizens  to  be  part  of  decision-making  processes  concerning  their  lives. As  a  pillar  of  socially  inclusive  governance,  it  directly  impacts  both  individual  well-being and  society  as  a  whole.

While  the  adoption  of  ICT  can  increase  accountability,  transparency,  and  legitimacy in governance  [1], it does not automatically enhance eParticipation -especially for marginalized  groups  [4].  Although  ICT  use  is  intended  to  expand  citizen  engagement  [5], in  practice,  new  barriers  arise,  some  of  which  result  from  persistent  inequalities  in  their access  and  use-  known  as  the  digital  divide  [4].  Even  among  those  who  overcome  this

'  IFIP  International  Federation  for  Information  Processing  2026

S.  Hofmann  et  al.  (Eds.):  ePart  2025,  LNCS  15978,  pp.  3-18,  2026.

divide,  barriers  may  persist,  as  some  individuals  may  feel  that  their  voices  are  ignored or  not  equally  valued  throughout  the  participation  processes  [6].  Any  of  these  disparities manifests  unequal  participation,  leaving  underserved  populations  underrepresented  or without  a  meaningful  platform  to  express  their  views  [7].

As  Brabham  [8]  notes,  'any  democratic  model  is  problematic  if  it  is  predicated  on access  to  something  that  not  everyone  has  access  to'  (p.  255).  Citizen  participation  can only  be  considered  meaningful  if  equitable  participation  opportunities  are  guaranteed  for all  individuals  [9].  As  Cornwall  [6]  underlines,  it  is  essential  to  examine  who  participates, who  is  excluded,  and  who  excludes  themselves,  while  developing  strategies  to  mitigate these  disparities.  Similarly,  the  commitment  to  'leaving  no  one  behind',  a  central  principle  of  the  UN  2030  Agenda  for  Sustainable  Development,  demands  explicit  efforts  to meaningfully  and  actively  include  marginalized  groups  in  participatory  processes.

Although  principles  of  inclusion  are  commonly  underlined,  research  in  eParticipation  has  not  kept  pace  with  these  commitments.  It  has  been  nearly  20  years  since  early eParticipation  characterizing  and  theorizing  efforts  were  recognized  [4,  10].  Yet,  significant  research  gaps  persist  due  to  a  diversity  of  conceptualizations  [11],  and  the  complex nature  of  the  interdisciplinary  play  of  technological,  political,  and  social  factors  [12]. Contemporary  studies  in  eParticipation  overlook  the  complexity  of  balancing  diverse interests  in  a  fair  and  equal  manner  [13]  while  placing  disproportionate  emphasis  on technological  aspects  [14].  As  a  result,  current  frameworks  often  fail  to  comprehensively  address  the  social  and  structural  barriers  of  achieving  inclusive  eParticipation. Further  research  is  therefore  needed  to  move  beyond  the  technical  frames  and  better account  for  the  diverse  needs,  capabilities,  and  motivations  for  engagement  across  citizens  of  various  socio-demographics  backgrounds  [9,  10].  This  is  the  only  way  to  improve the  inclusion  capacity  for  eParticipation-leaving  no  one  behind  [1].

To  bridge  these  gaps,  it  is  essential  to  first  understand  and  conceptualize  what  inclusion  in  the  eParticipation  context  truly  means.  With  this  objective  in  mind,  our  research aims  to  answer  the  question: 'How  can  inclusive  eParticipation  be  conceptualized?'. By  systematically  synthesizing  literature  across  five  academic  databases,  we  propose  a conceptual  framework  with  corresponding  dimensions,  which  can  support  practitioners with  a  standardized  approach  to  assess  and  improve  inclusion,  ultimately  leading  to  best practices.

## 2 Background  of  eParticipation  and  Inclusion

eParticipation  is  a  concept  that  has  emerged  due  to  the  digitalization  of  participatory spaces.  It  comes  from  the  diffusion  of  two  elements - 'e(lectronic)',  implying  the  use of ICT, with 'participation', which  refers to public involvement  in deliberation and decision-making  processes  [10].  Tools  that  can  facilitate  participatory  activities  are  of great  variety,  including  chat  technologies,  discussion  forums,  electronic  voting  systems, web  portals,  social  media,  groupware,  weblogs,  visualization  tools,  and  more  [10,  15, 16].  eParticipation  is  viewed  as  solution  to  growing  political  dissatisfaction  and  declining trust in public institutions [17],  as  it  provides  citizens  with  effective  communication and  informed  decision-making  tools,  while  improving  the  efficiency  and  legitimacy  of political  processes  for  governments  [10].

According  to  United  Nations  [3],  eParticipation  formats  include  eInformation,  eConsultation  and  eDecision-making.  eInformation  refers  to  the  use  of  digital  tools  to  provide  citizens  timely  access  to  public  information.  eConsultation  tools,  on  the  other  hand, enable  citizens  to  engage  in  discussions  through  real-time  interactions,  or  archived  audio and  video  recordings  of  public  meetings.  eDecision-making  goes  a  step  further  by  incorporating  citizen  input  into  the  final  decisions  and  following-up  on  how  these  contributions  have  influenced  the  policymaking  outcomes.  eParticipation  spans  a  wide  range  of areas,  including  polling,  voting,  campaigning,  participatory  law-making,  electioneering, cultural  politics,  urban  and  spatial  planning,  and  more  [15].

While  technologies  that  facilitate  engagement  are  rapidly  evolving,  the  field  of  eParticipation  is  still  at  a  relatively  early  stage  [4,  15,  16].  Research  has  primarily  focused  on the  technological  aspects,  while  the  social  issues  remain  underexplored;  an  imbalance Medaglia  [14]  argues  must  be  addressed.  To  advance  the  field,  it  is  crucial  to  understand and  navigate  these  challenges,  ensuring  that  eParticipation  not  only  leverages  technology effectively,  but  also  balances  the  benefits  and  social  risks  at  play.

The  concepts  of  inclusion  and  exclusion  were  first  coined  in  European  policy  discourse  as  broader  alternatives  to  the  narrower  concept  of  poverty  [18].  The  shift  was deemed  necessary  in  order  to  acknowledge  that  people  who  were  unable  to  integrate into  mainstream  society,  were  excluded  not  only  because  of  income  deprivation,  but also  due  to  educational,  employment,  cultural,  social  and  political  factors.  Mancinelli [19]  views  these  as  factors  of  disadvantage,  which  can  define  'the  relative  position  that an  individual  or  a  group  has  in  the  whole  context  of  the  society.'

Two  key  areas  of  social  exclusion  are  emphasized  by  Rawal  [18]  to  be  exclusion  from i)  participation  in  civil  society  and  ii)  social  arenas-both  linked  to  eParticipation.  The importance  for  eParticipation  processes  to  be  inclusive  and  fair  to  all  segments  of  society is commonly  underlined  [9,  20]. However,  'inclusion' is a fluid,  multidimensional, ambiguous  concept,  that  adapts  to  different  contexts  and  is  therefore  difficult  to  measure and  operationalize  [18].  Some  eParticipation  literature  links  issues  of  inclusion  to  the digital  divide.  Digital  technologies  are  not  equally  accessible  for  everyone - an  issue amplified  by  differences  in  digital  literacy  and  skills  [20].  Unequal  adoption  and  access to  ICT  deepens  the  gap  between  those  who  can  effectively  use  these  tools  and  benefit  from their  advantages,  and  those  who  cannot  [19].  Beyond  the  digital  divide,  some  studies also  consider  broader  aspects  of  inclusion.  Mariani  et  al.  [21],  for  instance,  highlight  the importance  of  ensuring  diversity,  representativeness,  and  a  balance  of  different  voices  in decision-making  processes.  This  is  echoed  by  Östling  [22],  who  raises  concerns  about the  equality  of  eParticipation,  ensuring  that  no  particular  group  or  interest  dominates the  process,  and  that  there  is  no  discrimination  against  specific  groups.  It  is  therefore not  sufficient  that  access  to  the  participatory  tool  is  granted,  the  public  should  also  feel that  their  voices  matter,  and  that  the  process  is  both  effective  and  fair  [6].  True  inclusion means  that  everyone  has  a  meaningful  opportunity  to  shape  decisions.

Ensuring  equality  and  inclusion  in  eParticipation  is  critical  for  maintaining  democratic  quality,  and  evaluating  these  processes  is  the  only  way  to  address  shortcomings. However,  as  there  is  no  established  understanding  of  what  inclusion  entails,  this  concept

is  difficult  to  measure.  A  conceptual  framework  is  necessary  to  clarify  the  core  dimensions  of  inclusion  in  eParticipation,  while  integrating  findings  from  diverse  disciplines to  create  a  holistic  understanding.

## 3 Research  Methodology

This  study  employs  a  Systematic  Literature  Review  (SLR),  which  is  a  highly  structured, and  reproducible  method  'for  identifying,  evaluating,  and  synthesizing  the  existing  body of  completed  and  recorded  work  produced  by  researchers,  scholars,  and  practitioners' (p.  6)  [23].  Considering  that  the  SLR  can  identify  what  is  known  or  unknown  about a research topic [24],  while  providing  'evidence  that  the  phenomenon  is  robust  and transferable'  (p.  2)  [25],  we  find  it  to  be  a  highly  suitable  approach  to  research  the  phenomenon  of  focus  for  this  study - inclusion  in  eParticipation.  This  systematic  review  follows  the  eight-step  guideline  by  Okoli  [26],  with  the  four  phases  of  Planning,  Selection, Extraction,  and  Execution  which  ensure  a  rigorous  methodological  process.

Planning. The  first  two  steps  of  the  review  involved  developing  a  search  strategy and  a  detailed  protocol,  to  ensure  consistency  throughout  the  process  and  among  the authors. The  search was  developed  in concert with the research question, to clearly reflect  the  review«s  purpose  and  goals.  Considering  the  topic«s  interdisciplinary  nature, and  the  aim  to  identify  the  highest  possible  number  of  relevant  studies  [25],  we  selected 5  different  online  bibliographic  databases:  Sage,  Taylor  and  Francis,  Wiley,  AISeL,  and ACM  Digital  Library.  The  literature  search  was  conducted  on  November  4 th ,  2024.

The  search  string  was  built  by  combining  terms  related  to  the  concepts  of  i)  citizen participation,  ii)  ICT  and  iii)  inclusion.  These  terms  include  synonyms,  abbreviations, and  alternative  spellings  [25],  to  encompass  the  different  ways  the  concepts  are  referred to  by  researchers.  To  increase  relevancy  of  results,  the  search  for  each  term  group  was limited  to  the  Abstract  field.  The  query  was  tested  and  edited  several  times  before  the final  search,  to  ensure  that  the  best  applicable  keywords  were  selected,  and  the  highest number  of  relevant  articles  was  achieved.  The  search  string  used  was  the  following:

Abstract:  ('eparticipation'  OR  'participation'  OR  'citizen  engagement'  OR  'citizen  participation'  OR  'community  engagement'  OR  'civic  engagement'  OR  'citizen involvement')  AND  Abstract:  ('ICT'  OR  'information  and  communication  technology'  OR  'electronic'  OR  'online'  OR  'digital'  OR  'virtual')  AND  Abstract:  ('inclusion'  OR  'inclusive'  OR  'einclusion'  OR  'exclusion'  OR  'equity'  OR  'equality' OR  'inequality'  OR  'inclusiveness'  OR  'inclusivity'  OR  'exclusive').

Overall,  1494  articles  were  found,  and  uploaded  on  the  digital  systematic  review management  platform  Rayyan.

Selection. Firstly,  duplicate  articles  were  automatically  identified  using  Rayyan,  with 24  removed  after  manual  resolution.  The  remaining  1470  articles  underwent  a  two-phase screening:  1)  title  and  abstract screening  and  2)  full-text screening.  Criteria  for their inclusion,  applied  in  both  screening  stages,  were  defined  before  starting  the  process,  and the  reasons  justifying  the  decision  were  documented.  Studies  were  eligible  for  inclusion if  they  i)  were  in  English,  ii)  had  accessible  full-text,  iii)  clearly  focused  on  eParticipation initiatives  and  iv)  addressed  social  aspects  relevant  to  inclusion.  A  quality  check  was additionally  done  to  ensure  that  articles  were  peer-reviewed  and  of  sufficient  standard.

The  lead  author  screened  1470  articles,  with  a  second  reviewer  independently  assessing a sample  at the beginning  of the screening process, to minimize  bias. Results were compared  to  establish a  shared  understanding  of  relevance,  and  disagreements  were resolved  through  discussion.  After  title-and-abstract  screening,  the  number  of  articles was  narrowed  down  to  220.  These  were  taken  forward  for  full-text  review,  resulting  in 27  final  inclusions  (Fig.  1.).

Fig.  1. Selection  process

<!-- image -->

Extraction  and  execution. Each  paper«s  general  characteristics  were  initially  mapped using  Excel.  This  was  followed  by  the  text  analysis,  using  a  thematic  approach  where codes were developed  in an inductive manner.  According  to Bandara  et al. [27], in this  approach  the  included  literature  is  treated  as  a  qualitative  data  set,  and  themes  are purely  derived  from  its  analysis.  We  utilized  open,  axial,  and  selective  coding  techniques [27],  which  were  carried  out  in  an  iterative  manner.  Each  article  was  first  read  in  full  to identify  the  relevant  text,  and  open  coding  was  performed  using  Zotero.  The  excerpts  and labels  were  then  imported  into  a  Microsoft  Word  document,  to  identify  the  relationships between  them,  and  develop  conceptual  links-a  process  known  as  axial  coding.  Selective coding  was  then  performed  to  organize  the  identified  dimensions  as  part  of  the  6  concepts for  inclusion  in  eParticipation,  described  in  the  findings  section  below.

## 4 Findings

Of  the  27  articles  included,  23  are  journal  papers  and  4  are  conference  proceedings.  19 of  the  articles  are  published  between  2020-2025,  7  between  2010-2019,  and  only  one  in 2008.  The  studies  report  from  a  variety  of  countries  including  USA,  Kenya,  South  Africa, Canada,  Australia,  New  Zealand,  Philippines,  but  mostly  European  countries-Estonia, Austria  and  Greece,  Germany,  UK,  Switzerland,  Netherlands,  Czechia,  Slovakia,  France, and  Finland.  The  articles  are  themed  into  6  conceptualizations  of  inclusion  for  eParticipation  with  19  dimensions.  The  concepts  are:  Access,  Knowledge,  Motivation,  Safety, Impact,  and  Empowerment.

## 4.1 Access

A  key  theme  throughout  the  articles  concerns  the  accessibility  of  eParticipation,  both in terms of i) the infrastructure necessary to be part of these processes, and ii) the accessibility  of  the  tool  or  format  selected.

Infrastructural. Having access to digital infrastructure is a prerequisite for being included in participatory activities. Digital infrastructure includes  device  ownership, internet service, and connectivity  infrastructure,  whose  availability  varies across different  demographics,  contexts,  and  geographic  regions.  While  adoption  of  ICT  tools intends  to  lower  the  access  threshold  by  overcoming  time  and  distance  limitations,  it  has also  introduced  a  new  layer  of  exclusion-unequal  technology  access  [28].  This  affects certain  social  groups  disproportionally,  reinforcing  existing  inequalities  [29].

Suitable  devices  are  essential  resources  for  eParticipation  [35].  However,  because  of socio-economic  reasons,  not  everyone  is  able  to  afford  modern  ICTs  [29,  30].  Availability of  smartphone  devices  can  additionally  be  a  concern  for  people  with  disabilities  [31,  32]. Depending  on  the  nature  of  their  limitations,  they  are  less  likely  to  use  mobile  devices  or engage  in  online  activities  [31].  Affording  digital  services  presents  another  obstacle  to inclusion.  Economically  disadvantaged  individuals  might  not  be  able  to  cover  the  costs of  mobile  data  and  broadband  plans  [30]  or  face  the  lack  of  connectivity  infrastructure, especially  for  people  who  live  in  rural  areas  [30,  34].  Many  remote  populations  face fundamental  infrastructure  deficits,  such  as  stable  electrical  power,  or  cellular  coverage, which  makes  inclusion  in  eParticipation  initiatives  impossible.

Addressing  these  structural barriers necessitates  interventions on multiple levels, including  infrastructural  investments,  process  strategies,  and  policy  measures  aimed  at improving  digital  access  [34-36].  These  strategies  must  account  for  economic  disparities, diverse  abilities,  and  geographic  inequalities  in  embedded  infrastructure.

Design-Related. Having  access  to  the  basic  infrastructure-devices,  the  internet,  and connectivity-is  only  the  first  step  towards  inclusive  eParticipation.  Equally  important is  the  accessibility  of  the  participatory  formats  themselves.  The  choice  of  technology facilitating  the  process  is  a  decisive  factor  in  who  can  access  the  activity.  Considering financial  disparities  across  different  demographics,  the  selected  tool  should  be  compatible  with  a  range  of  different  hardware  to  prevent  entry  barriers  [34].  Ensuring  the  equal usability  of  this  technology  among  different  devices  is  additionally  essential,  because not  everyone  owns  multiple  diverse  devices,  and  can  afford  switching  to  the  better  one [28].  Beyond  hardware  compatibility,  usability  is  a  key  determinant  of  access  [29,  32,  33, 37].  Functional,  intuitive  layouts  should  allow  all  users  to  access  information,  interact with  others,  and  give  their  input  with  ease.

A  crucial  consideration  in  tool  design  is  balancing  functionality  and  simplicity.  Highquality deliberation is important, but so is avoiding inequalities in the participation depth of different groups. The technological and functional characteristics of a tool influence  participation,  with  only  a  select  group - often  those  with  higher  educational backgrounds - able  to  navigate  overly  complex  designs  and  utilize  their  deliberative potential [35, 38]. Addressing  these obstacles requires well-designed platforms that combine  accessibility  with  meaningful  deliberation,  along  with  stronger  legal  pressures ensuring  the  technological  needs  and  preferences  of  diverse  demographics  are  met  [39].

## 4.2 Knowledge

Knowledge  is  the  next  theme  which  stems  from  differences  between  potential  participants'  skills  in  digital  literacy,  discursiveness,  language,  awareness,  or  domain-specific understanding.

Digital Literacy. Low  levels of digital literacy can hinder individuals from  participating,  despite  infrastructural  access  and  well-designed  tools.  Digital  literacy  includes multiple competencies,  such  as keyboard,  mobile, and touchscreen  skills, data literacy,  and  experience  or  familiarity  with  specific  ICT  tools  [30,  35].  This  literacy  is  not binary,  and  people  can  have  varying  levels  of  proficiency  across  the  different  aspects, which  impact  both  user  confidence  and  willingness  to  engage  [34,  40].  Limited  digital skills, often linked to lower educational  backgrounds  or  income  levels  [30, 41], reinforce  existing  divides  in  society.  To  enhance  inclusion,  assessing  users'  skill  levels and  providing  targeted  digital  literacy  training  is  essential  [30].  Longer-term  support and  capacity-building  interventions  are  also  crucial  [34],  as  one-time  training  may  not ensure  sustained  engagement  [34].

Discursiveness. Another  key  factor  impacting  people«s  ability  to  participate is their discursive  skills  [40].  This  refers  to  their  comfort  using  complex  discussion  languages, expressing  themselves  clearly,  understanding  others'  arguments,  and  collaborating  effectively.  Research  links  limitations  in  these  skills  to  lower  education  levels,  as  structured reasoning  and  formal  argumentation  require  significant  cognitive  effort  [38].  This  can result  in  exclusion  or  reduced  participation  from  meaningful  debates.

Domain-Specific  Understanding. A  lack  of  or  limited  knowledge  on  the  specific  issue under  deliberation  can  also  act  as  a  barrier  to  inclusive  engagement  [42,  43].  The  complexity  of  a  topic  influences  levels  of  participation  [43],  potentially  discouraging  certain  individuals  from  expressing  their  voice.  It  is  therefore  critical  to  provide  relevant preparatory  materials,  effective  communication  of  complex  information,  and  facilitated dialogue,  to  bridge  knowledge  gaps  and  support  equal  and  meaningful  engagement  for everyone  [42].

Language. Language  presents  another  significant  criterion  for  inclusive  participation. This can impact  migrant  communities,  who  may  not  be  proficient  in  the native  language.  If  they  have  difficulties  in  understanding  or  communicating  effectively,  meaningful  engagement  becomes  unfeasible  [28,  44].  However,  if  the  provided  information is  overly  technical  or  rigid,  it  can  be  difficult  to  understand  and  engage  with,  even  for native  speakers  [28,  32].  This  issue  can  impact  both  the  ability  to  participate  in  discussions,  but  also  the  learnability  of  digital  tools  and  interfaces.  Communication  should  be accessible  to  all,  through  support  mechanisms  such  as  translators,  cultural  mediators,  or multilingual  materials  [44,  45],  as  well  as  clear,  simple  terminology,  free  of  excessive technical  terms  [32].

Awareness. Lack  of  awarenesses  is  a  multifaceted  issue,  stemming  from  a  knowledge gap  about  participation  opportunities,  the  relevance  of  participation  in  daily  life,  or  individuals«  role  in  the  process  [28,  30].  This  can,  for  instance,  impact  immigrants,  who may  not feel included  by the term 'citizen' and assume  they«re  not part of the targeted  participants.  Awareness  gaps  also  include  capability  awareness,  where  individuals

- especially  those  with  low  digital  skills - do  not  see  the  value  of  digital  engagement formats  [28].  Some  forms  of  awareness  can  be  built  through  better  information  dissemination,  while  others  are  linked  to  deeply  rooted  social  issues  and  require  sustained  effort. Therefore,  awareness-building  should  be  a  central  concern,  especially  for  the  inclusion of  low-income  and  low-education  demographics  [30].

## 4.3 Motivation

Beyond  access  and  knowledge  barriers,  motivation  can  also  present  a  divide  for  inclusive eParticipation  processes.  This  can  be  of  political form,  but also linked  to the topic«s relevance,  time,  and  incentives.

Political. Political  motivation  is  shaped  by  political  activity  and  political  trust.  The  former  influences  an  individual«s  experience  and  interest  in  political  matters.  Engaging  in activities  like  political  meetings,  signing  petitions,  and  opinion  leadership  [33]  increases the  likelihood  of  participating  in  deliberative  processes.  High  interest  moreover  correlates  with  greater  internet  use  for  information  seeking,  protesting,  or  producing  political content  [41].  The  link  between  political  activity  and  participation  is  cyclical,  as  people who  are  more  interested  are  more  likely  to  engage.  This  experience,  in  turn,  boosts  political  efficacy  and  knowledge  and  therefore  further  involvement  [41,  46].  However,  these patterns  are  greatly  impacted  by  demographic  differences,  such  as  gender  [41],  age  [46], race  [47],  and  disability  status  [31].

Political  trust  plays  a  more  complex  role.  Low  trust  can  deter  participation,  if  individuals  believe  that  the  process  will  not  lead  to  a  meaningful  change - often  due  to  past failures  where  decisions  did  not  account  citizens«  input  [28].  On  other  cases,  mistrust  can serve  as  a  trigger  for  action  [40],  if  individuals  see  engagement  as  a  way  of  taking  matters into  their  own  hands.  This  can  be  explained  by  the  distinction  between  trust  in  'politics' (the  actors  within  the  political  system)  and  trust  in  the  'polity'  (the  functioning  of  the democratic  system  as  a  whole).  Those  who  trust  the  system  but  not  the  political  actors, act  as  'critical  citizens',  engaging  in  political  activities  to  push  for  change,  despite  their skepticism  [33].

Relevance  of  Topic. Participation  requires  emotional,  physical,  and  mental  investment, making  personal  relevance  of  the  issue  a  key  motivator  [42].  Individuals  factor  in  the potential  drawbacks  of  participating  before  deciding  if  getting  involved  is  worthwhile. This  particularly  impacts  marginalized  groups,  such  as  people  with  disabilities,  who face  greater  exposure  to  challenges  like  online  harassment  [39,  48].  However,  if  an  issue is highly  relevant,  people  are  likely to  engage  despite  potential  risks  [48].  To  ensure inclusive and meaningful  participation,  discussions  must  therefore resonate with the public  at  large  as  well  as  diverse  social  groups.

Temporal  Barriers. Although  ICT  use  aims  to  mitigate  time  constraints,  deliberative activities are tasks that must be balanced with social and economic  responsibilities [28].  Participation  is  often  viewed  as  a  leisure  activity  [28]  making  it  lower  priority  for those  juggling  (multiple)  jobs,  family,  or  personal  commitments.  The  cost  of  time  is particularly  significant  for  certain  social  groups,  like  the  economically  disadvantaged, who  must  prioritize  income-generating  opportunities  [30].  When  gendered  social  norms

intersect  with  economic  and  rural  factors,  these  barriers  become  manifold.  Programs must  therefore  understand  these  dynamics  at  play  and  strive  to  cater  to  the  diverse  needs and  constraints  of  diverse  groups.

Incentives. Another key factor for inclusion is incentives. Gift cards or monetary rewards  can  motivate  those  who  may  otherwise  need  to  prioritize  responsibilities  like work  or  economic  concerns  over  engagement  [28,  41].  Recognition  or  compensation  also helps  make  certain  groups,  such  as  historically  exploited  marginalized  communities,  feel that  their  time  and  effort  are  genuinely  valued  [28].

## 4.4 Safety

Safety  is  a  critical  criterion  for  all  different  social  groups  to  feel  welcome  and  comfortable in  engaging  in  electronic  participation.

Privacy  and  Security  Needs. Individuals  need  to  feel  that  their  privacy  is  respected  and that  participating  does  not  negatively  expose  them  [44].  These  concerns  are  amplified  in digital  spaces,  where  the  risks  of  data  leaks  or  hacking  are  more  pronounced  [32].  Beyond external  security  threats,  the  risk  of  being  identified  and  targeted  can  be  a  significant challenge.  If  recognizable  identifiers  are  not  protected,  citizens  are  at  a  risk  of  facing retaliation when  reporting unethical practices or negative feedback  [32].  Vulnerable social  groups,  such  as  people  with  disabilities  [39],  or  asylum-seekers  [44]  are  also  likely to  face  higher  scrutiny  or  discrimination  if  identified.  If  they  are  forced  to  choose  selfprotection  over  engagement  [48],  the  process  can  no  longer  be  considered  inclusive,  as their  voices  will  not  be  represented.  It  is  critical  that  ICT  design  ensure  trust  and  integrity, giving  assurance  that  participants«  information  is  securely  stored  and  safeguarded  [44]. Data  protection  policies  should  be  easily  attainable,  for  everyone  to  be  well  informed of how  their data is handled  [32]. Privacy through  design, such as filter bubbles, or anonymity  control  features  [39,  49],  ensures  the  burden  of  managing  their  security  does not fall solely on individuals  [48]. This can minimize  the  potential  risks of political involvement  and  empower  people  to  engage  without  fear  [48,  50].

Power  Dynamics. Safety is additionally determined by the interactions and  power dynamics  among  different socio-demographic  groups, which can manifest in disrespectful  exchanges  or  discriminatory  language.  Individuals  from  marginalized  backgrounds  are  more  likely  to  experience  harassment  or  personal  attacks,  making  them  feel unwelcome  or  unsafe  in  deliberative  spaces  [39,  44].  These  fears  are  common  among racial  minorities,  who  may  be  exposed  to  discrimination  and  unfair  treatment  in  engagement  activities,  both  on  and  offline  [49].  Exclusionary  communication  can  also  stem from  social  stereotyping  and  elitism  based  on  ethnic,  class,  or  lifestyle  differences  [50]. Power  imbalances  may  not  always  be  overtly  aggressive,  but  still  determine  whose  voices dominate  discussions  and  whose  are  silenced  -  often  evident  in  gender  differences  [42]. Active  efforts  are  necessary  to  ensure  safe  and  respectful  interactions,  where  everyone feels  comfortable  and  open  to  voicing  their  opinions.  The  design  of  the  process  plays a  critical  role  in  ensuring  everyone  can  actively  engage,  rather  than  allowing  a  few  to dominate  the  conversation  [51].  Moderators  should  moreover  follow  established  rules which  help  facilitate  equal  discussions,  free  from  bias  [42,  43].

## 4.5 Impact

For  eParticipation  to  be  deemed  inclusive,  satisfaction  with  the  outcome  plays  a  key role.  This  concerns  two  factors,  responsiveness  of  the  organizers  of  the  process,  and transparency  and  fairness  of  how  decision-making  is  carried  out.

Responsiveness  of  Organizers. Citizens  need  to  see  that  the  input  they  contribute  with is  considered  and  acted  upon,  in  order  to  perceive  their  engagement  as  meaningful  [32]. This  is  an  impactful  factor  when  calculating  whether  to  engage  or  not,  especially  for the  less  advantaged  groups  [30].  A  responsive  solution  is  keeping  participants  updated after  each  stage  with  information  and  a  timeline  about  the  upcoming  steps  [45].  Another way  to  support  these  expectations  is  to  disseminate  information  about  successful  and impactful  previous  discussions  [42].  It  is  moreover  critical  for  the  official  to  be  present in  discussions,  to  ensure  that  all  targeted  groups  have  confidence  in  the  chance  for  real impact.

Transparency  and  Fairness  in  Decision-Making. To  ensure  the  inclusiveness  of  eParticipation  processes,  decision-making  should  moreover  strive  to  be  as  fair  as  possible, in  terms  of  how  different  interests  are  represented  [40].  It  is  critical  for  individuals  to believe  that  their  participation  is  fair  and  meaningful,  and  they  should  be  able  to  see  the fruits  of  their  engagement  in  the  final  deliberation  product  [52].  However,  processing and  analyzing  input  generated  during  deliberation  is  a  demanding  task,  and  the  factors that  determine  which  interests  will  be  better  served  are  manifold.  To  ensure  that  the  final decision  is taken  in a fair manner,  transparency  of  how  input  is  evaluated  is  critical. People  should  be  able  to  see  how  their  position  compares  to  the  overall  result,  and  how arguments  influenced  the  outcome  [52].  Digital  tools  can  support  this  by  making  everyone«s  contributions  and  the  decision  criteria  visible  [37].  Such  mechanisms  should  be  a legal  requirement,  to  enhance  transparency  and  accountability  of  organizing  actors,  and promote  the  fair  evaluation  of  different  interests,  even  if  not  all  are  reflected  in  the  final decision  [32].

## 4.6 Empowerment

Individuals must  feel that they are capable, supported, and recognized  as legitimate political  actors,  to  feel  empowered  to  participate.  This  empowerment  can  be  impacted and shaped  by self-belief, social networks,  cultural-specific  approaches,  and  agency development.

Self-belief. People  may  experience  a  lack  of  confidence  as  a  significant  barrier  to  inclusion.  Even  if  other  criteria  for  inclusion  in  eParticipation  are  met,  individuals  may  feel uncomfortable  or  hesitant  to  express  their  views  and  share  their  perspectives  with  others [28].  This  often  stems  from  negative  self-perception,  shaped  by  power  imbalances  [28] and  an  internalized  sense  of  one«s  'place  in  social  hierarchies'  [30].  Such  barriers  are particularly  problematic  for  vulnerable  groups,  like  the  younger  generation,  who  may feel  that  issues  concerning  them  are  often  discussed  without  their  input,  or  that  their engagement  would  make  little  difference  [29].  This  exclusion  reinforces  a  cycle  of  disempowerment.  Similarly,  economically  disadvantaged  individuals  often  experience  low

self-esteem  tied  to  a  sense  of  powerlessness  as  years  of  exclusion  can  create  a  'culture of  silence',  where  individuals  no  longer  see  the  value  of  their  opinions  [30].  When  people  internalize  the  belief  that  their  voices  do  not  matter,  disengagement  is  not  simply a  personal  choice,  but  a  reflection  of  the  structural  inequalities  and  deep-rooted  power hierarchies.

Social  Network. Another  aspect  which  determines  empowerment  is  the  social  capital an  individual  possesses.  Social  networks-including  schools,  marketplaces,  churches, community  centers,  family,  and  friends-form  the  immediate  structures  that  shape  daily interactions  and  provide  essential  support  [35].  A  strong  social  network  has  a  positive effect  on  individuals'  attitudes,  skills,  and  confidence,  empowering  them  to  participate both  online  and  offline  [35,  36].  An  existing  network  lowers  the  threshold  for  engagement  in  eParticipation,  by  fostering  a  sense  of  belonging,  facilitating  opinion-sharing, and  providing  reinforcement  for  individuals'  views.  Without  pre-existing  connections, participation  becomes  more  difficult,  as  individuals  must  put  forth  active  efforts  to  foster a  sense  of  community  on  these  platforms  [49].  Engaging  alone  additionally  comes  with a greater risk of speaking  up  on  an  issue as  an  individual,  whereas  collective  action mitigates  this  [49].

Cultural  Needs. Inclusion  cannot  be  a  one-size-fits-all  approach.  Cultural  specificities significantly  shape  how,  and  to  what  extent,  individuals  can  engage  in  eParticipation. These  influences  manifest  in  various  forms.  For  example,  Bickerton  and  Löfgren  [48] show  that  political  engagement  within  New  Zealand«s  social  networks  is  often  perceived negatively, discouraging  individuals from openly expressing their views. To prevent cultural  norms  from  becoming  barriers  to  participation,  it  is  critical  to  recognize  these dynamics  and  actively  mitigate  their  negative  impacts.  Culturally  sensitive  approaches should  be  integrated  to  create  engagement  opportunities  that  are  meaningful  and  relevant to  diverse  demographics  and  their  values  [49],  for  instance  migrant  communities,  who may  struggle  to  navigate  new  social  and  legal  contexts  [44].  A  key  challenge  lies  in  the tendency  to  treat  minority  communities  as  a  homogenous  entity,  overlooking  internal differences.  Many  individuals  do  not  fit  within  one  community,  as  their  sense  of  identity is  created  by  an  interplay  of  cultural,  racial,  religious,  national,  and  social  affiliations [49].  Cultural  distances  should  therefore  be  acknowledged,  and  strategies  should  adopt flexible,  rather  than  standardized  approaches,  to  accommodate  diverse  sensitivities  and needs  [44].

Agency. Inclusion  efforts  require  a  shift  in  how  marginalized  individuals  are  perceived and  integrated  into  eParticipation  [39].  People  with  disabilities,  for  instance,  are  often categorized  as  vulnerable  and  in  need  of  protection,  which  reinforces  a  protective  rather than  empowering  approach.  It  is  critical  to  move  beyond  this  passive  medical  model and  mainstream  inclusivity  by  fostering  agency  in  participants  [39].  Instead  of  creating separate  digital  spaces  custom  to  specific  needs,  which  can  lead  to  isolation,  marginalized users  should  be  involved  in  co-designing  the  participatory  tools  and  programs.  Their perspectives  can  help  shape  digital  spaces  that  are  functional  for  all,  thereby  creating autonomous  digital  citizens  and  legitimate  political  actors,  rather  than  passive  recipients of  support  [39].

## 5 Discussion

<!-- image -->

Language

Fig.  2. Conceptual  Framework  for  Inclusive  eParticipation

In  this  SLR,  we  asked 'How  can  inclusive  eParticipation  be  conceptualized?'. Visualized  in  Fig.  2,  we  demonstrate  how  inclusion  can  be  understood  through  19  key  dimensions  for  inclusive  eParticipation,  within  the  6  core  concepts  of  accessibility,  knowledge, motivation,  safety,  impact,  and  empowerment.  In  the  below,  we  relate  the  framework to  existing  eParticipation  literature  and  illuminate  its  core  implications  for  research  and practice  on  eParticipation.

First  of  all,  determinants  of  eParticipation  in  our  framework  display  an  intersectional character,  meaning  that  different  forms  of  power  structures  and  demographic  variables overlap  in  determining  people's  position.  As  theorized  by  Crenshaw  [53],  intersectionality  involves  the  coincidence  of  different  structures  in  shaping  the  position  of  the  individual:  for  instance,  gender,  ethnicity  and  economic  position  concur  to  shape  a  person's strength  or vulnerability  in  a  given  setting.  The  same  is  observed  in  our  framework, where  concepts  of  accessibility,  knowledge  and  impact  divides  concur,  among  others, to  shape  an  individual's  position.  Recent  works  in  the  IS's  space,  e.g.  [54,  55],  highlight the  importance  of  an  intersectional  lens,  and  illuminate  its  role  as  a  guiding  device  in eGovernance  research.

Secondly,  our  conceptual  framework  identifies  accessibility,  knowledge,  motivation, safety,  impact,  and  empowerment  as  the  shape  for  inclusiveness  in  eParticipation.  This means  that  the  identified  concepts  act  jointly  in  shaping  eParticipation,  and  are  predicated on  each  other  in  such  a  way  that  one  will  affect  the  other  [56].  This  view  of  inclusive eParticipation  problematizes  mono-dimensional  approaches  often  seen  in  the  included corpus  of  literature,  which  mainly  focuses  on  isolated  factors  such  as  technical  or  designrelated  ones.  Our  framework  challenges  this  issue  and  invites  instead  holistic  approaches,

such  as  sociologies  of  governance  [57],  that  capture  the  mutual  and  dynamic  relation among  dimensions.  Developing  this  framework,  we  have  noted  that  a  holistic  approach can make  explanatory sense of eParticipation and be a basis for future  expounding efforts  [58].  Further  research  should  focus  on  empirically  validating  this  framework  and exploring  potential  missing  dimensions  and  the  interplay  among  them.  This  includes examining  perspectives  from  both  citizens  and  experts  involved  in  the  process-an  angle often  overlooked  in  the  reviewed  articles,  which  tend  to  prioritize  one  over  the  other.

Finally,  we  submit  that  our  conceptual  framework  can  help  adjust  the  ways  in  which strategies  and  efforts  for  inclusive  practices  can  be  focused.  Building  inclusion  means engaging  an  effort  of  stakeholder  harmonization,  which  the  6  mutual  concepts  identified in  our  framework  can  support.  The  different  dimensions  are  relevant  to  the  construction of  inclusive  practices.  For  example,  impact  divides  have  been  dealt  with  in  recent  ICT for  Development  (ICT4D)  research,  in  the  light  of  their  incidence  on  data  justice  and  its achievement  [54].  At  a  time  of  high  practical  relevance  of  eParticipation,  it  is  important that  a  holistic  approach  is  taken  to  it,  exploring  how  different  dimensions  affect  its  uptake among  people.

A  key  limitation  of  this  review  is  the  potential  for  selection  bias  due  to  language and  database  restrictions,  which  may  have  excluded  some  relevant  articles.  Expanding the  study  to  other  databases  and  languages  could  be  an  interesting  avenue  for  future research,  reducing  this  bias.

## 6 Conclusion

Through  a  systematic  literature  review,  we  identified  the  multidimensional  nature  of inclusive  eParticipation,  shaped  by  the  core  concepts  of  access,  knowledge,  motivation, safety,  impact,  and  empowerment.  We  offer  a  conceptual  framework  with  a  holistic  lens, using these  conceptualizations  and  the  19  dimensions.  This  framework  can  serve  as a  valuable  basis  for  practitioners  and  policymakers  to  evaluate  initiatives  and  understand where  efforts should focus to improve  inclusiveness  of engagement  activities. Ultimately,  advancing  inclusive  approaches  remains  essential  for  eParticipation  to  fulfill its  democratizing  potential.

## The  Socio-Technical  Factors  That  Influence the  Use  of  E-Participation  in  Rural  Uganda

Josephine  Ayebare ( B ) and  Steven  Sam

Brunel  University  London,  Uxbridge,  England,  UB8  3PH,  UK

{josephine.ayebare,Steven.Sam}@brunel.ac.uk

Abstract. There  is  limited  research  that  presents  both  technical  and  non-technical factors  that  influence  e-participation.  The  aim  of  the  paper  is  to  identify  technical and  non-technical  factors  that influence  e-participation  design  and  use  in rural Uganda.  This  was  achieved  by  drawing  on  Isingiro  District's  citizens  and  government  leaders'  experiences  and  socio-technical  context  data  through  43  in-depth interviews.  The  study  shows  that  a  wide  range  of  individual  factors,  institutional and  socio-cultural  practices  hinder  uptake  of  usage  of  ICTs  in  political  participation  and  some  enabling  factors.  Our  study  lays  the  foundation  for  researchers, governments,  policymakers,  and  e-participation  designers  to  identify  necessary conditions  for  designing  effective  e-participation  models  and  systems  in  settings similar  to  rural  western  Uganda.

Keywords: Socio-technical  Factors · E-participation · Rural · E-participation Factors · Non-technical  Factors · E-participation  Technical  Factors

## 1 Introduction

Citizen  participation  in  deliberative  democratic  processes  is  one  of  the  significant  topics in  government  administration,  particularly  as  the  demand  for  Information  Communication  Technologies  (ICTs)  to  enhance  citizen  engagement  increases  [7]  and  its  global adoption  expands  [19].  ICTs  refer  to  the  use  of  digital  technologies  like  radio,  television, computers,  internet,  mobile  devices,  and  personal  computer  kiosks  to  produce,  capture, process,  store,  send,  receive,  access  and  manipulate  information  [9].  The  use  of  ICTs  to facilitate  interactions  between  government  and  citizens  to  achieve  inclusive  deliberative and  participatory  decision-making  processes  is  referred  to  as  electronic  participation (e-participation)  [32].  The  demand  to  use  e-participation  is  driven  by  the  ability  of  the technologies  to  enable  governments  to  engage  a  wider  audience  of  citizens  more  efficiently  and  conveniently  while  promoting  transparency  and  accountability  [11].  Some other  advantages  and  benefits  of  e-participation  consist  of  optimizing  governance,  promoting  transparency,  improving  public  services,  and  empowering  citizens  compared  to traditional  participation  channels  [35,  36].  Additionally,  e-participation  has  perceived advantages  of  reducing  time  and  costs,  driving  economic  growth,  and  enhancing  political  freedoms  [37,  38].  Despite  the  spread  and  perceived  advantages  of  e-participation, the  progress  of  its  use  remains  limited  particularly  in  developing  countries  [25,  39].
