## From  Promise  to  Practice:  Exploration of  Differences  in  Digital  Citizen  Participation in  a  Municipal  Context

<!-- image -->

Petra  Sintorn ( B )

<!-- image -->

University  of  Gothenburg,  Gothenburg,  Sweden petra.sintorn@ait.gu.se

Abstract. Digital  citizen  participation  has  attracted  scientific  interest  for  decades, particularly  as  participation  platforms  have  been  implemented  and  adopted  in  the public  sector.  Although  progress  has  been  made  to  overcome  immature  technology  and  low  user-friendliness,  digital  citizen  participation  still  faces  challenges. The  promising  potential  to  enhance  co-creation  and  create  public  value  is  often not  realised.  Various  forms  of  citizen  participation,  including  the  digital  platforms used,  need  to  be  further  explored.  In  our  theoretically  informed  case  study,  we  use the  3A 3 framework  (Actors,  Arenas,  Aims),  comparing  two  distinct  digital  participation  initiatives  within  the  same  municipal  context.  Our  contribution  highlights how  differences  in  rationale,  structure,  and  interpretation  of  citizen  input  leads to  divergent  outcomes,  either  as  optimisation  (structured,  goal-oriented  participation)  or  innovation  (open,  creative  participation).  We  also  demonstrate  the  organisational  challenges  of  adapting  to  open  models  of  participation  and  how  managed participation  fits  more  easily  into  existing  bureaucratic  structures.  For  municipalities  and  policy  makers,  we  offer  practical  insights  on  how  to  design  and  implement digital  participation  initiatives  that  are  both  meaningful  and  manageable.

Keywords: Digital  citizen  participation · Digital  government · Participation platforms

## 1 Introduction:  The  Challenge  of  Digital  Citizen  Participation in  Digital  Government

The  public  sector  is  under  pressure  due  to  complex,  economic,  environmental,  and  societal challenges [1]. One  way  to strengthen democracy  and  give the opportunity for citizens  to  influence  policy  impact  has  been  digital  participation  [2-4].  Citizen  participation  carries  ambitions  of  addressing  the  issue  of  distrust  and  to  facilitate  social  change [5,  6],  and  many  scholars  have  suggested  that  digital  technologies  can  improve  citizen participation  [7,  8].

Digital  government  has  moved  from  the  digitizing  of  government  services,  to  exploring  how  information  and  communication  technologies  (ICT)  can  drive  transformative

S.  Hofmann  et  al.  (Eds.):  ePart  2025,  LNCS  15978,  pp.  241-256,  2026.

<!-- image -->

change  across  the  public  sector  [9].  This  evolution  encompasses  enhancing  service  delivery  to  integration  of  'the  digital'  into  governance  processes  and  leveraging  advanced algorithms  and  AI  [9-11].  The  implementation  of  digital  participation  platforms  is  driven by  the  objective  of  reinforcing  the  democratic  dialogue  and  enhancing  the  level  of  participation  in  decision-making  processes  [12],  increase  the  quality  and  anchoring  of  policies but  also  to  enhance  legitimacy  and  trust  for  the  democratic  processes  [2,  13].

To foster digital participation, a paradigm shift is required from traditional approaches  to  digital  transformation  in  government.  It  means  that  public  organizations need  to  adopt  new  roles,  by  becoming  more  interactive  and  facilitative  ([14,  15],  while also  embracing  greater  openness  and  transparency  [16-18].  For  a  shift  to  happen  in  how participation  is  shaped  and  understood,  technology,  people,  and  processes  need  to  be integrated  [19],  implementing  new  technology  alone  will  not  redefine  the  value  propositions  [20].  When  adopting  participation  in  a  public  organisation  there  needs  to  be  an understanding  of  the  conditions  that  shape  the  digital  transformation  process,  as  well  as the  underlying  democratic  and  political  rules  that  govern  it  [21,  22].

There  is  a  lack  of  understanding  of  how  different  types  of  digital  participation  initiatives  function  in  terms  of  their  structure,  purpose,  and  outcomes.  Existing  research  often treats  digital  participation  as  a  monolithic  concept,  without  sufficiently  distinguishing between  open-ended  and  guided  forms  of  participation  or  analyzing  how  these  differences  affect  implementation  and  impact.  In  this  study  I  compare  two  cases  of  digital citizen  participation  implemented  in  a  Swedish  municipality.  The  ambition  is  to  explore and  understand  how  they  are  shaped  by  analysing  them  across  arenas,  actors  and  aims. Thus,  the  present  study  focuses  on  the  following  research  question:

What  are  the  most  significant  differences  between  open  and  guided  digital  citizen participation  initiatives  and  how  do  these  differences  manifest?

## 2 Digital  Platforms  for  Citizen  Participation

There  are  many  reasons  why  governments  try  to  pursue  digital  citizen  participation,  to foster  trust  and  revitalise  local  democracy  [5,  6],  but  it  is  also  as  a  way  to  develop  digital services  [23]  spur  co-creation  [3]  or  discuss  urban  planning  [24].  The  use  of  platforms for  digital  participation  emerging  in  the  late  2000s  [25]  has  led  to  an  intense  exploration where  governments  try  to  enhance  digital  citizen  participation  [7,  8],  including  hopes for  better  inclusion  of  marginalized  groups  [26],  lowering  barriers  of  participation  [27], driving cost-effective participation and participation of scale [28]. But despite years of  investment  in  digital  transformation  initiatives,  there  are  deep-seated  issues  such  as institutional  readiness  that  hinder  digitalisation  [29,  30]  and  digital  government  adoption is  still  low  [31].

From  the  classical  work  of  Arnstein,  power  and  decision-making  are  central  themes that  constitute  the  target  of  citizen  participation  [32].  Today  many  citizen  participation initiatives  have  a  consultative  role  rather  than  an  impact  on  decisions  [33],  sometimes even  the  consultative  part  is  absent,  and  governments  implement  citizen  participation initiatives  to  legitimise  decisions  [22,  34].  In  this  study  digital  citizen  participation  is aligned  with  the  definition  'the  extension  and  transformation  of  participation  in  societal democratic  and  consultative  processes  mediated  by  information  and  communication

technologies  (ICT),  primarily  the  Internet.  It  aims  to  support  active  citizenship  with  the latest  technology  developments,  increasing  access  to  and  availability  of  participation  in order  to  promote  fair  and  efficient  society  and  government.'  [35].

The  digital platforms  used  in  our study  collect the  opinions  from  citizens  on  the behalf  of  the  city  and  government,  but  they  also  encourage  and  provide  a  channel  for involvement  in  the  development  of  the  city  [36,  37].  Platforms  have  both  been  categorised and evaluated in prior research, but there is still no common  way  of  doing  so [21, 25, 37]. Previous  research  disagrees  on  the  ability  of citizen participation  to  address citizens'  interests,  some  show  how  it  can  lead  to  social  change  [38],  while  others  claim that  citizen  participation  empowers  the  already  privileged  [33].  Reasons  why  platforms are  not  used  and  therefore  not  making  an  impact  can  relate  to  issues  of  trust  [39],  low involvement,  poor  design  and  technology  know-how,  these  have  all  been  found  critical factors  for  successful  digital  participation  [40-46].  Usability  and  simplicity  are  factors that  influence  how  one  gets  involved,  but  there  are  also  in-depth  studies  that  show  that details  in  the  functionality  can  be  decisive  [47],  and  minor  changes  can  make  differences in  participant  behavior  [48].

Research  supports  the  idea  that  using  digital  participation  platforms  can  attract  new groups  to  be  involved  in  planning,  better  reach  out  with  planning  projects  and  ideas  but also  gather  local  knowledge  and  build  trust  [49].  Urban  developments  are  important  to  the government,  and  as  it  affects  the  everyday  life  of  the  citizens,  they  also  have  incentives  for being  engaged  [28].  But  although  platforms  and  technologies  have  evolved,  the  organizational  and  contextual  factors  that  shape  their  effectiveness  remain  underexplored.  There is  limited  empirical  insight  into  how  municipalities  integrate  these  platforms  into  their governance  processes,  and  how  this  integration  (or  lack  thereof)  influences  the  success of  participation  efforts.  In  this  study,  we  do  not  focus  specifically  on  the  technical  design or  use  of  the  participation  platforms,  as  the  literature  shows  that  digital  systems  per  se do  not  successfully  involve  citizens  despite  their  potential  for  large-scale  participation. Instead,  we  see  the  platform  in  its  context,  and  its  integration  into  the  organization.

## 3 Research  Design

## 3.1 Research  Setting

We  conducted  our  study  in  a  medium-sized  Swedish  municipality  with  around  100,000 inhabitants  and  6,000  employees,  between  January  and  June  2023.  We  are  studying  two citizen  participation  initiatives,  we  call  them  'Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue'  and  'Case 2  -  Comprehensive  Plan'.

## Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue

The  citizen  dialogue  is  held  in  different  parts  of  the  municipality  and  each  dialogue  lasts for  a  period  of  six  weeks  when  citizens  can  meet  civil  servants  and  politicians  in  open forums  or  add  their  proposals  in  the  digital  participation  platform  used  for  the  dialogue. This  hybrid  type  of  dialogue  means  that  several  meetings  are  held  combined  with  the digital platform  open  for  proposals.  The  budget  to  finance  citizens  proposals  is  0,43 MEUR  per  year  and  funding  decisions  are  made  by  a  board  of  politicians.  This  form  of dialogue  originates  from  policies  that  imposes  participatory  decisions  between  elections

[26]  but  also  a  strong  tradition  of  participation  and  the  view  of  citizens  as  active  creators of  their  society  [33].

The  platform  used  in  this  initiative  is  built  on  a  global  open-source  platform  called Decidim  [25].  The  platform  was  introduced  in  this  Swedish  municipality  in  2019  and implemented  because  the  pandemic  restricted  how  the  municipality  could  meet  with citizens.  The  platform  is  governed  by  civil  servants  and  in  the  platform  anyone  can  post and  search  for  proposals.  If  you  are  registered,  proposals  can  be  followed  or  commented on  but  there  is  no  voting  for  proposals.  There  are  no  restrictions  for  what  proposals  that can  be  posted  but  there  are  guidelines  to  support  the  users.  The  citizen  participation  in this  initiative  is  open  and  created  by  the  municipality  to  listen  and  understand  its  citizens better  and  provide  a  channel  for  impact.

## Case  2  -  Comprehensive  Plan

During  spring  2023,  the  municipality  carried  out  a  dialogue  to  give  citizens  the  chance to  participate  in  creating  the  new  comprehensive  plan.  The  comprehensive  plan  is  regulated  in  the  Planning  and  Building  Act  and  the  Environmental  Code  [50].  The  creation of  the  comprehensive  plan  is  extensive  since  it  includes  many  important  decisions  such as  guidelines  for  sustainable  development  and  how  to  preserve  the  existing  environment. The  platform  used  for  this  dialogue  is  called  Placetoplan  [25].  The  platform  was  introduced  to  engage  citizens  and  collect  their  ideas  exclusively  for  the  comprehensive  plan. The  platform  was  proposed,  published,  governed  and  edited  by  consultants.  Citizens could  access  the  platform,  navigate  via  a  map  and  respond  to  predefined  questions  or add  comments  connected  to  an  area  on  the  map.

Table  1. Participation  uptake

|                                                                 | Case 1- Citizen Dialogue   | Case 2 - Comprehensive Plan   |
|-----------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------|-------------------------------|
| Platform                                                        | Decidim                    | Place-to-plan                 |
| Number of participants in total                                 | 98                         | 700                           |

## 3.2 The  3A 3 -framework  of  Participation

To  be  able  to  compare  the  two  cases  of  digital  citizen  participation  initiatives,  we  use the  conceptual  framework  called  3A 3 -framework  of  participation  [51].  The  framework builds on Arnstein's seminal  paper  on the participation ladder [32],  to  combine  and unpack  the  concept  of  participation.  The  framework  consists  of  three  components:  the surrounding  context,  the  planning  process  itself  and  third,  the  participation  process.  The participation  process  is  divided  into  three  dimensions  of  participation  (Fig.  1);  actors, who  participates, 'who?',  their roles and how  they are recruited to participate.  The

second  dimension  is  Arenas  which  deals  with  the  structure  of  the  participation  process, 'how?'.  It  tries  to  capture  the  places,  the  form,  and  the  rhythm.  The  third  dimension  is Aims,  'Why?',  and  deals  with  the  issues,  motives  and  outcomes  of  participation.  These should  be  seen  as  a  network  of  interactions  between  the  different  dimensions.  The  3A 3 framework  can  also  be  used  operationally  as  a  tool  to  navigate  the  different  options  and opportunities  for  participation  [51].

When  understanding  how  digital  participation  is  shaped  and  developed,  the  framework  can  be  used  as  an  analytical  tool  to  analyze  similarities  and  differences,  which  this study  aspires  for.  The  framework  was  derived  from  urban  planning  studies,  which  fits well  with  the  digital  participation  initiative  that  we  intend  to  analyse;  both  have  strong focus  on  planning  and  designing  the  urban  space.  Through  the  framework  I  study  the implications  of  actors,  arenas  and  aims  in  shaping  digital  citizen  participation.

## 3.3 Data  Collection

In  this  theoretically  informed  case  study  [52],  I  draw  on  the  theoretical  concept  developed  by  Hofer  &amp;  Kaufmann  [51].  This  builds  upon  existing  theoretical  frameworks  of participation  which  we  consider  reliable  for  informing  our  research  question.  Theory  is integrated  into  the  case  study  research  to  establish  connections  between  the  findings  and relevant  theoretical  frameworks  and  research  [52,  53].  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue  and Case  2  -  Comprehensive  Plan,  both  aim  to  engage  citizens  to  participate  in  developing their  community.  The  cases  were  selected  because  they  occur  in  the  same  institutional setting,  a  Swedish  municipality  (the  surrounding  context  in  the  framework),  and  target  the same  community.  However,  they  differ  in  how  participation  is  implemented.  Therefore, I  wanted  to  explore  these  cases  more  deeply  to  understand  how  the  differences  manifest.  Numerous  municipalities  implement  digital  participation  in  a  comparable  manner, consequently,  valuable  lessons  can be drawn  from  this study with regard to  broader application.

From  January-June  2023  I  have  collected  archival  data,  performed  interviews  and been  involved  on  the  field  doing  observations,  attending  meetings  and  events  (table  1).

Interviews  were  conducted  online  and  in  physical  meetings,  interviews  were  recorded with  consent,  translated  from  Swedish  to  English,  and  transcribed  for  analysis  (Table  2).

## 3.4 Data  Analysis

In  the  analysis,  I  used  the  3A 3 -framework  of  participation  [51]  and  its  dimensions  and  elements  analysing  how  these  are  reflected  in  the  data.  Multiple  data  sources  were  used;  the digital  participation  platforms,  archival  documents,  observations,  reports,  pre-studies, public  communication  related  to  the  projects,  notes  from  project  meetings  and  interviews  with  key  roles  (see  Table  1).  Moving  back  and  forth  between  the  case  data  and  the conceptual  framework,  using  an  abductive  process  [54]  whereby  coded  for  the  framework  dimensions  while'  staying  open'  for  discovering  new  dimensions.  This  iterative process  allowed  identifying  patterns  and  discovering  the  similarities  and  differences.

The  initial  step  in  the  analysis  was  to  identify  and  comprehend  arenas,  aims  and  actors in  each  case,  followed  by  the  analysis  of  its  constituent  elements.  This  was  achieved  by

employing  a  tabular  representation,  wherein  the  elements  were  systematically  mapped and  then  compared.  This  facilitated  the  identification  of  both  commonalities  and  divergences.  Thereafter,  the  focus  shifted  to  a  more  in-depth  exploration  of  these  divergences in  the  two  cases.  The  next  phase  involved  a  more  detailed  examination  of  the  data  in order  to  analyse  the  components  related  to  the  elements  that  could  clarify  and  advance the  understanding  of  how  the  divergences  manifested  themselves  in  the  cases.

## 4 Findings

Study  of  Arenas:  Both  conducted  open  meetings  with  citizens  as  well  as  with  targeted groups.  These  meetings  were  carried  out  in  a  similar  manner,  regarding  the  spaces  used, the  frequency  of  meetings,  and  their  rhythm.  What  emerged  as  a  significant  difference were  the  digital  platforms  and  formats  used,  prompting  us  to  analyze  this  aspect  more thoroughly.

Analysis  of  Actors:  We  found  that  both  recruitment  and  subjects  were  similar;  they were staffed by and targeted similar groups. However,  we  found  that the proposals and  information  gathered  from  the  citizens  were  handled  using  different  approaches.  A difference  we  found  was  linked  to  the  roles  of  the  civil  servants  and  how  they  performed in  processing  and  editing  the  input.

Emphasis  on  Aims:  The  data  revealed  a  strong  emphasis  on  the  dimension  of  aims. It  became  evident  that  all  three  elements;  issues,  rationales,  and  outcomes  significantly influence  the  shape  and  differentiation.  We  highlight  this  importance  in  our  analysis  and create  an  understanding  of  its  impact  (Fig.  2).

Fig.  2. Remodeled  version  highlighting  differences

## 4.1 Rationale + Format:  Open  vs  Guiding

There is a clear distinction regarding the rationale for citizen participation. In  Case 1  -  Citizen  Dialogue,  citizen  participation  can  be  regarded  as  an  end  in  itself,  whereas in  Case 2 - Comprehensive  Plan,  citizen  participation  serves  as  a  means  to  create  a

comprehensive  plan  regulated  by  law  [50],  and  from  the  steering  document  one  can read  that  it  is  '…  a  sub-project  within  the  framework  of  the  comprehensive  plan  and will  deliver  results  to  the  process'.  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue  on  the  other  hand,  can be  described  as  a  dialogue  for  the  sake  of  a  dialogue.  The  municipality  perceives  it  as beneficial  to  engage  in  such  discourse  and  to  demonstrate  a  willingness  to  listen  and consider  the  opinions  of  its  citizens.  This  is  reflected  in  their  policy  document  which states: 'It is important to incorporate residents' experience and knowledge  of local conditions  into  decision-making  and  implementation'.  Case 2 - Comprehensive  Plan  is a  component  of  a  larger  process  where  citizens'  opinions  are  collected  in  to  serve  as  one of  several  supporting  elements  in  the  formulation  of  a  comprehensive  plan.  Participation thus  has  a  discernible  objective  and  is  not  an  end  in  itself.

In  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue,  participation  as  an  end  implies  an  openness  for  participants  to  contribute  freely  based  on  their  ideas  and  thoughts.  This  is  reflected  in  the platform's  call  to  action:  'Y ou  can  help  change  your  neighborhood'.  However,  this  openness  also  creates  ambiguity,  that  can  make  it  challenging  for  participants  to  focus  their opinions  or  understand  the  specific  areas  where  input  is  most  valuable.  Consequently, which  is  visible  in  the  reports,  many  of  the  comments  received  are  not  relevant  or  related to  the  municipality's  services  or  areas  of  concern.  This  is  manifested  in  the  platform  as a  simple  form  where  the  user  can  post  whatever  proposal  they  want.  The  starting  point is  a  blank  sheet  without  any  direction  for  the  user.  Few  citizens  use  the  platform  to  post suggestions,  the  usage  statistics  shows  that  the  uptake  is  minimal.  Moreover,  there  is no  particular  reason  to  express  an  opinion  and  no  sense  of  urgency.  This  means  that everyone  can  participate  but  also  (perhaps)  that  no  one  is  necessarily  interested  because there  is  no  issue  that  attracts  attention.

The  fact  that  participation  itself  can  be  said  to  be  the  goal,  makes  it  complicated  to link  what  is  collected  to  something  that  can  be  acted  upon.  The  absence  of  a  defined problem  and  the  focus  on  citizen  expression  complicate  the  establishment  of  a  cohesive link  between  these  diverse  perspectives  and  the  objectives  of  administrations.  It  is  diffuse  how  and  where  the  proposals  should  be  addressed,  who  should  be  responsible  for implementing  them  and  how  it  should  be  done.  There  is  no  clear  timeline  and  for  those involved  it  is  unclear  if  or  when  anything  will  be  acted  upon.  This  is  reinforced  by  the  fact that  those  who  work  with  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue  belong  to  the  central  administration and  that  the  integration  into  the  organisation  is  weak.  Several  civil  servants  involved  in collecting  proposals  mention  that  it  is  challenging  to  find  someone  to  drive  and  realise the  ideas  that  are  submitted.

Case  2  -  Comprehensive  Plan  has  a  clearer  intention  and  purpose  that  can  create motivation  to participate. You  can  only participate right now;  this is your chance  to influence  the  comprehensive  plan,  expressed  in  marketing  as:  'your  thoughts  and  ideas are  important  and  can  contribute  to  the  municipality's  new  comprehensive  plan'.  There is  a  defined  and  limited  purpose  and  a  sense  of  urgency  that  can  attract  and  motivate citizens. This is also reflected in the configuration of the platform, where  there are questions  and  a  definition  of  what  type  of  contribution  that  is  asked  for,  thus  enabling the  creation  of  a  comprehensive  plan.  The  platform  has  an  interactive  map  and  a  set of  themes  and  questions  that  guides  the  user,  creating  clarity  and  simplicity.  This  is  a

deliberate  intention  and  in  project  meetings  there  was  a  consensus  that  questions  should not  be  'to  open'  and  contributions  should  consultative  (Fig.  3).

Fig.  3. Comparing  platforms  comprehensive  plan  (left)  and  citizen  dialogue  (right)

## 4.2 Issues + Roles:  Degree  of  Interpretation  as  Governing

In  both  cases,  the  civil  servants  involved  are  a  relatively  small  number  of  employees belonging  to  the  central  administration.  There  is  a  main  project  manager  for  each  of  the initiatives  who  organizes  the  work,  liaises  with  the  supplier,  compiles  the  results  and reports  them  to  the  politicians.  The  analysis  of  the  data  reveals  that  the  way  in  which the  expertise  of  the  civil  servants  is  expressed  and  utilized,  which  may  appear  similar at  first  glance,  differ  significantly.  In  Case 1 - Citizen  Dialogue,  the  role  of  the  project manager  is  the  development  of  democratic  processes,  facilitate  participation,  and  possess  the  knowledge  required  to  make  appropriate  recommendations  aligned  with  the municipality's  decision-making  mandate.  Once  a  proposal  has  been  received,  it  will  not be  distorted  or  interpreted  by  the  project  manager  or  the  politicians;  rather,  a  proposal is  preserved  in  its  original  form.  The  civil  servant  in  charge  of  the  process  present  the proposals  to  the  politicians  together  with  a  recommendation,  they  then  determine  which proposals  that  should  be  implemented  and  financed.  These  reports  from  the  citizen  dialogues  are  simply  lists  of  proposals  in  its  originated  form.  Not  interpreting  the  proposals at  all  can  have  consequences,  the  project  manager  remember  situations  where  'it  has happened  that  a  citizen  makes  a  suggestion,  I  have  investigated  it  (..)  and  came  to  the conclusion  that  this  is  the  closest  we  can  do,  (…)  then  the  politicians  say  it's  a  good proposal,  but  it's  not  close  enough  to  what  the  citizens  want'.  As  opposed  to  undertaking an  action  that  might  be  tantamount  to  the  desired  outcome,  no  action  will  be  taken.

In  Case  2  -  Comprehensive  Plan,  the  proposals  received  serve  as  a  foundation  for the  urban  planners  to  further  analyse  and  interpret.  They  may  consolidate  similar  proposals,  identify  patterns  in  the  material,  and  develop  principles  and  directions  for  the comprehensive  plan  based  on  the  proposals  submitted.  This  process  involves  utilizing the  expertise  of  the  urban  planners  and  integrating  their  ideas  with  those  of  politicians to  facilitate  a  decision  on  a  new  comprehensive  plan.  The  input  provided  by  citizens represents  one  element  of  the  process,  but  there  are  other  factors  considered.  The  project

manager  means  that  'it  becomes  an  analysis  grid  on  that,  you  pick  out  certain  things and  where  you  analyse  in  a  certain  way  and  compile  in  a  certain  way.  It's  always  very difficult  because  everything  is  possible'.

Politicians  are  involved  in  both  processes,  in  the  dialogue  initiative  they  make  decisions  about  funding  from  a  shortlist  of  proposals  recommended  by  the  project  manager. In  Case  2  -  Comprehensive  Plan  the  politicians  will  eventually  decide  upon  a  comprehensive  plan  for  10-15  years  ahead  where  the  participation  from  citizens  serves  as one  input  among  others.  Urban  planners  do  their  interpretation  of  the  material,  and  they process  it  before  it  becomes  a  document  presented  to  the  politicians.  There  are  several levels  of  interpretations,  and  the  urban  planners  are  expected  to  use  their  expertise  to produce  this  document.  In  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue,  the  level  of  interpretation  is  almost none,  the  proposals  are  evaluated  and  decided  upon  as  they  were  written  by  the  citizens.

## 4.3 Format + Outcome:  The  Intertwining  of  Temporality  and  Tangibility

The  two  cases  demonstrate  differences  in  the  implementation  of  the  platforms,  their appearance  and  the  manner  of  interaction  with  citizens.  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue  is participation  with  the  ambition  to  give  citizens  the  opportunity  to  influence  their  local area.  There  is  a  budget,  and  feasible  proposals  can  be  financed  by  the  municipality.  There is  a  willingness  to  listen,  and  the  dialogue  has  an  ambition  to  strengthen  the  image  of the  municipality  and  the  mutual  trust  between  citizens  and  the  municipality.

The  two  cases  differ  in  their  time  horizons.  Case  2  -  Comprehensive  Plan  involves a  focused  effort  to  gather  citizens'  opinions  and  thoughts  on  what  their  neighborhood should  look  like  in  the  future,  the  project  manager  says:  'we  hope  to  discuss  (…)  longterm  development  together  with  our  citizens.  That  is,  how  they  see  the  future  and  the physical  environment  now  and  20  years  ahead'.  It  aspires  to  be  visionary  and  longterm,  in  a  dialogue  that  takes  place  right  now.  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue  is  short-term, focusing  on  the  immediate  desires  of  citizens,  examples  of  proposals  from  the  aggregated list  include:  better  food  in  school,  open  air  cinema  and  seating  for  elderly.

The  discrepancy  between  these  temporalities  means  divergent  outcomes;  Case  1  Citizen  Dialogue  shows  tangible  results  in  proposals  that  are  decided  on,  given  a  budget and  implemented.  There  is  also  an  idea  of  active  citizens,  strengthened  trust  and  relationship  building.  In  the  context  of  the  comprehensive  plan,  the  result  is  intangible,  a plan  is  to  be  formulated  and  the  input  from  citizens,  after  interpreted  by  urban  planners, becomes  an  integral  part of that plan. The  process  is  visualised  and  how  their  opinions  will  be  treated  and  what  the  final  product  will  be  handled,  something  that  creates trust  [55].  There  is  a  timeline,  and  it  will  be  possible  to  follow  the  political  process  and decisions  that  will  be  taken  in  the  future.  It  is  hoped  that  this  is  something  that  can  be realised  in  the  long  term  and  aligned  into  the  municipality's  infrastructure  and  environment.  Once  the  new  comprehensive  plan  is  developed  and  adopted,  it  will  be  accessible and  presented  to  citizens.  Case  2  -  Comprehensive  Plan  has  yielded  a  tangible  outcome in  the  form  of  a  proposal  for  a  comprehensive  plan.  However,  the  absence  of  a  concrete result  until  the  development  of  the  comprehensive  plan  can  also  be  argued.

## 5 Discussion

Using  the  3A 3 framework  [51]  the  analysis  highlights  how  two  participation  initiatives diverge  and  how  their  differences  manifest.  A  considerable  body  of  research  has  been dedicated  to  investigating  the  levels  of  impact  and  the  factors  that  determine  participation. This  has  highlighted  challenges  related  to  representativeness  and  inequality  [24,  33,  38, 40].  This  study  takes  the  organisational  perspective  and  from  prior  research  we  know that  public  sector  organisations  have  a  focus  on  achieving  efficiency  rather  than  being innovative,  and  the  adaptation  and  ability  to  change  is  limited  [56].  Scholars  have  argued that  embeddedness  and  integration  in  governance  as  a  way  to  foster  participation  [14, 24,  57].

The  present  study  indicates  challenges  connected  to  adaptation  and  change  when proposals  are  received  that  cannot  be  addressed,  nor  implemented.  Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue  is  open  and  unstructured,  a  form  of  participation  facing  obstacles  in  the  bureaucratic  and  non-adaptive  organisation  such  as  a  municipality.  The  comprehensive  plan  on the  contrary,  has  a  clear  process  where  participation  is  guided  and  outcomes  are  managed  in  a  predetermined  manner.  The  structure  aligns  with  the  municipality's  established governance  and  can  be  regarded  as  optimisation  of  participation  (Fig.  4).

Fig.  4. Differences  leading  to  participation  as  innovation  or  optimisation

<!-- image -->

## 5.1 Digital  Participation  as  Optimisation

Our  analysis  of  the  differences  and  how  they  manifest  leads  us  to  interpret  Case 2 - Comprehensive  Plan  as  optimisation  of  participation.  In  this  form  of  participation,  citizens are  involved  with  the  aim  of  contributing  to  the  development  of  the  existing  structure in  a  clear  and  well-defined  process.  In  the  platform,  the  user  is  prompted  to  respond  to leading  questions,  generating  the  necessary  information  for  the  process.  The  user  cannot deviate  or  submit  alternative  ideas  What  is  collected  undergoes  an  analysis  and  interpretations  are  made  of  the  compiled  contribution  from  the  participants.  Civil  servants  write a  report  that  is  proposed  to  the  politicians  and  according  to  a  pre-agreed  process,  which is  eventually  approved  in  accordance  with  laws  and  regulations.

Participation  as  optimisation  is  a  form  of  participation  that  the  organisation  is  well positioned  to  implement.  It  is  consistent  with  the  governance  and  structure  that  admits well-defined,  smaller  developments.  This  does  not  pressure  the  organisation  to  be  transparent  or  responsive,  other  than  the  process  that  has  already  been  established.  The  participation  platform  had  a  substantial  uptake  of  citizens  contributing  to  the  comprehensive plan.  The  organisation's  ability  to  manage,  control  and  direct  participation  as  optimisation  ensures  its  potential  in  achieving  the  desired  level  of  participation,  contribution  and results.

## 5.2 Innovative  and  Creative  Digital  Participation

Case  1  -  Citizen  Dialogue  is  built  on  an  assumption  that  citizens  want  to  participate in  the  democratic  life  and  that  they  understand  and  see  this  as  their  responsibility.  The platform  does  not  tell  the  user  what  to  submit,  it  is  open  for  any  ideas  and  opinions. The  proposals  received  are  not  distorted,  in  fact  they are  not  in  any  way  interpreted, merely  put  forward  the  way  they  were  written.  Ideas  can  be  bold,  crazy  and  completely misaligned.  The  interaction  needed  to  advance  new  ideas  does  not  take  place  [58],  thus most  proposals  become  shelf  warmers.  The  lack  of  feedback  and  capability  of  turning new  ideas  into  reality  makes  the  citizens  (and  the  civil  servants)  call  it  a  'participation game'  -  participation  that  does  not  have  the  ability  to  create  impact  [59].  Of  course, this  is  no  surprise  that  one  of  the  most  prominent  challenges  governments  face  is  to adapt  and  change,  be  more  innovative  and  creative.  This  explains  the  challenges  that many  organisations'  experiences  when,  with  their  best  intentions,  they  try  to  open  up  for participation,  but  since  this  is  actually  about  exploration  the  organisation  does  not  have the  capabilities  to  facilitate  this  approach.

The  inherent  conflict  is  whether  participation  needs  to  be  guided  and  limited  to  be considered  effective  and  beneficial.  Our  results  indicate  that  participation  is  more  likely to  succeed  when  there  is  a  clear  expectation  of  the  input  needed,  combined  with  guiding questions  and  explicit  instructions  on  how  to  participate.  What  might  be  perceived  as open  and  creative,  the  possibility  to  participate  on  one's  own  terms  and  offer  any  opinion and  suggestion  can  instead  become  obstructive.  The  lack  of  clarity  makes  it  difficult achieve  meaningful  results  and  the  absence  of  feedback  fosters  distrust.

## 5.3 Implications  for  Practice  and  Research

Historically,  Swedish  municipalities  have  engaged  in  initiatives  that  encourage  citizen participation  [33],  characterized  by  an  almost  naive  view  that  all  participation  is  inherently  positive.  There  has  been  a  focus  on  the  potential  benefits,  overshadowing  the  risks of  eroding  trust  that  can  occur  when  citizen  participation  fails  to  produce  tangible  results [2].

This  research  shows  that  there  is  a  need  to  clarify  and  be  able  to  distinguish  different types  of  participation  that  the  municipalities  deploy.  We  have  shown  that  participation, despite  being  characterized  as  open  to  new  ideas,  does  not  have  the  prerequisites  to  create change.  This  is  because  innovative  modus  operandi  is  difficult  and  not  yet  accomplished, although  called  for  [60].  Conversely,  participation  that  is  integrated  into  well-defined projects are better equipped  to  succeed  as  municipalities  know  how  to  manage  and

implement  optimisation.  This  study  has  expanded  our  understanding  and  definition  of participation,  introducing  a  connection  to  optimisation  and  innovation.  Using  Hofer's 3m 3 as  an  analytical  tool  [51]  has  demonstrated  differences  in  participation  and  how they  manifest.

The  question remains  for municipalities whether  they should continue to  implement  what  they  have  mastered,  namely  optimisation;  clear  processes  that  guide  citizens. This  participation  is  characterised  by  its  ability  to  deliver  on  its  promises.  However,  it does  not  demonstrate  any  intention  to  influence  or  innovate.  Do  municipalities  need  to change  in  order  to  genuinely  harness  the  ideas,  and  potentially  the  skills,  of  their  citizens?  The  creation  of  citizen-centred  innovation  may  be  a  prerequisite  for  enhancing  the trust  between  citizens  and  municipalities.  The  present  study  does  not  seek  to  provide  a definitive  answer  to  these  questions;  rather,  it  identifies  an  area  for  future  research.

Numerous  municipalities  are  implementing  digital  participation in  a  comparable way, and therefore valuable lessons can be learnt from  this study in terms of  wider application.  This  does  not  mean  that  this  study  is  without  limitations.  The  use  of  the  3A 3 framework  [51]  provided  an  analytical  tool  with  a  strong  focus  on  arenas,  aims  and  actors and  the  ability  to  analyse  and  understand  differences  based  on  these.  However,  using  an inductive  approach  might  provide  a  richer  and  more  nuanced  picture  of  differences  as no  boundaries  are  set.

Abstract. With  their  broad  service  portfolio,  strict  regulations,  and  often  scarce resources,  municipalities  face  specific  requirements  and  challenges  for  mastering  digital  transformation.  While  maturity  assessments  have  become  a  common means  of  improving  project  management  at  the  organizational  level,  there  is  no domain-specific  approach  yet  that  focuses  on  digital  project  management  in  municipalities.  This  article  reports  on  the  development  and  evaluation  of  ECoProMD,  an Easy  Communal  Project  Maturity  model  for  Digitalization.  Based  on  an  extended understanding  of  maturity  models  as  a  combination  of  model  and  method,  we  used situational  method  engineering  to  design  and  validate  the  ECoProMD  artifact.  A literature  review  and  19  interviews  with  seven  municipal  experts  from  Germany provided  the  knowledge  base  for  this  research.

Keywords: Maturity  Model · Continuous  Maturity  Assessment · Digital  Project Management · Local  Government · Municipality

## 1 Introduction

<!-- image -->

Effective  project  management  (PM)  is  a  key  enabler  of  digital  transformation  in  public  administration,  ensuring  that  technology-driven  initiatives  are  successfully  implemented,  aligned  with  strategic  goals,  and  deliver  tangible  improvements  in  public  service delivery  [1].  In  the  public  sector,  digital  projects  often  involve  complex  stakeholder  environments,  regulatory  constraints,  and  long-term  impacts  on  administrative  structures  [2]. Without  mature  PM,  municipalities,  like  other  organizations,  risk  project  delays,  budget overruns,  and  failures  that  undermine  public  trust  and  digital  government  objectives  [3, 4].

Digital  PM  has  evolved  to  address  these  challenges  within  the  ongoing  digital  transformation  in  business,  public  service,  and  society.  It  can  be  defined  as  the  'combination of  traditional  project  management  and  the  full  adoption  of  digital  tools  and  technologies  in  the  management  of  projects'  [5].  Its  main  benefit,  compared  to  the  traditional

'  IFIP  International  Federation  for  Information  Processing  2026

S.  Hofmann  et  al.  (Eds.):  ePart  2025,  LNCS  15978,  pp.  257-271,  2026.

approach,  is  an  improved  ability  to  manage  project-related  information,  which  enables increased  effectiveness  and  efficiency  in  project  planning,  execution,  and  control  [5,  6] While  digital  PM  can  be  seen  as  an  adaptation  of  PM  to  the  challenges  and  requirements of  digital  transformation,  it  is  also  often  (but  not  only)  applied  for  managing  digitalization projects  [5].

Maturity  assessment  [7]  is  a  well-established  strategy  to  evaluate  an  organization's PM  capability  effectiveness  and  efficiency,  benchmark  it  with  other  organizations,  and improve  it  systematically  [8-10].  Despite  the  many  existing  PM  maturity  models  (PM3), there  is  no  domain-specific  model  yet  that  focuses  on  the  particular  requirements  and challenges  of  municipalities  for  mastering  digital  transformation  [11].  To  close  this  gap, our  research  is  guided  by  the  question:

RQ:  How  can  municipalities  determine  the  maturity  level  of  their  digital  project management capability, improve it, and consolidate it?

Based  on  this  question,  our  objective  is  to  design  a  tailored  maturity  model  for  digital PM  of  municipalities  as  the  smallest  units  of  local  government  (usually  a  city,  town,  or village). The  purpose  of  the  new  PM  maturity  model  is  to  support  municipalities  in advancing  their capability to deliver successful digitalization projects. For  increased utility and practical impact  of our research, we  focus  both on the model  and  on  the method  character  of  maturity  assessment  [12].  Consequently,  we  designed  an  artifact that  integrates  a  maturity  model  and  a  method  for  using  the  model  to  manage  maturity. As  a  result,  this  paper  presents  the  ECoProMD  model  and  method,  an  Easy  Communal Project  Maturity  model  for  Digitalization.

## 2 Theoretical Background and Related Work

The  purpose  of  maturity  models  is  to  identify  strengths  and  weaknesses  in  certain  areas of  organizations.  The  concept  has  its  origins  in  quality  management,  aiming  to  establish continuous  improvement  processes  and  optimize  product  quality.  In  1979,  Crosby  [13] described  a  concept  of  successive  maturity  levels  that  provides  a  simple  but  effective analysis  and  measurement  tool.  Maturity  models  became  more  widely  known  in  software  engineering  with  the  introduction  of  the  Capability  Maturity  Model  (CMM),  later extended  to  CMMI  (CMM  Integration)  [14].  Since  then,  the  basic  concept  has  been expanded  and  transferred  to  other  disciplines  (e.g.,  business  process  management)  and is  also  used  for  PM.  Cooke-Davies  [15]  reported  over  30  specialized  maturity  models for  PM  existing  in  2001.

Facing  the  many  proposed  models,  several  comparative  studies  have  been  published over  the  years  that  examine  and  evaluate  selected  models  (e.g.,  [9,  16,  17]).  Frameworks for  PM  maturity  model  (PM3)  comparison  with  multi-criteria  evaluation  were  proposed by  Man  [18]  as  well  as  Domingues  and  Ribeiro  [19].  Other  practice-oriented  studies explore  the  adoption  and  application  of  PM3s  (e.g.,  [20-22]).

With  a  more  fundamental  view,  Mettler  [12]  discusses  maturity  model  development and  application  based  on  a  design  science  research  (DSR)  perspective.  He  conceptualizes maturity  models  as  hybrid  artifacts  being  'somehow  in-between'  a  model  (state  descriptions,  i.e.,  the  maturity  levels)  and  a  method  (key  practices)  prescribing  the  systematic

use  of  the  model.  The  DSR  perspective  is  also  adopted  by  other  studies  investigating the  procedure  and  principles  of  designing  domain-specific  maturity  models  (e.g.,  [2325]). In their recent article, Stoiber et al.  [26]  draw  on  Mettler  [12]  and  the  method character  of  maturity  models  to  advocate  for  continuous  maturity  assessments,  which they  found  not  supported  by  many  existing  models.  To  extend  and  advance  traditional principles  of  maturity  assessment,  they  propose  the  Continuous  Maturity  Assessment Method  (CMAM)  [26].

Only  a  few  studies  shed  light  on  PM  maturity  in  public  administration.  Irfan  et  al. [3] investigated maturity of PM  as an  antecedent to organizational reputation based on  a  sample  of  425  respondents  from  the  project-based  public  sector  organizations  of Pakistan.  The  reported  findings  indicate  a  significant  positive  relationship  between  PM maturity  and  the  reputation  of  public  sector  organizations.  Bezerra  et  al.  [27]  conducted a  systematic  literature  review  to  identify  barriers  to  maturity  in  PM  in  the  public  sector. Of  the  seven  presented  barrier  dimensions,  'management  methodology',  'human  relations',  'organizational  structure',  and  'alignment  with  the  organization's  business'  are directly  related  to  PM.  Consequently,  the  authors  emphasized  the  need  for  benchmarking  practices  in  the  PM  context  and  the  integration  with  strategic  management.  A  recent literature  study  on  existing  PM3s  in  public  administration  by  De  Rosa  [11]  found  that although  some  of  the  identified  models  basically  could  be  applied  to  public  administration,  'substantial  modifications  are  necessary  to  make  them  operational  and  effective in  the  public  sector'.  Furthermore,  the  maturity  models  discussed  do  not  consider  any specific  characteristics  of  digitalization  projects  in  public  administration.

As  a  result,  it  can  be  stated  that  many  of  the  existing  maturity  models  fail  to  provide  a simple  but  sound  model  with  low-threshold  access  for  local  authorities  of  different  sizes due  to their complexity  (e.g.,  extensive  catalogs  of criteria and  capabilities).  Central success  factors  and  best  practices  in  the  project  environment  of  public  administration are  also  not  incorporated  to  the  necessary  extent.  In  the  following,  our  development  focus will  therefore  be  on  reducing  complexity  and  adding  specific  success  factors  concerning the  public  administration  domain  as  well  as  providing  clear  guidance  on  how  to  use  the model.

## 3 Research Design and Methods

Given  our  research's  objective,  we  decided  on  a  DSR  approach  [28,  29]  considering the  recommendations  of  previous  studies  on  developing  maturity  assessment  models [23-25,  30].  In  line  with  Mettler  [12],  we  understand  the  design  artifact  maturity  model as  a  combination  of  a  model  and  a  method  prescribing  the  systematic  use  of  the  model. Consequently,  we  draw  on  the  method  engineering  methodology  as  a  guiding  process within  our  DSR  approach  to  construct  and  validate  the  artifact.

## 3.1 Situational Method Engineering

Method  engineering  is  used  in  IS  [31]  as  'the  engineering  discipline  to  design,  construct and  adapt  methods,  techniques  and  tools  for  the  development  of  information  systems' [32].  Based  on  the  design  principle  of  reuse  [33],  the  assembly  of  situational  methods  for

specific  engineering  contexts  by  selecting,  adapting,  and  synthesizing  method  fragments from  existing  method  knowledge  has  become  an  established  practice  under  the  name of  situational  method  engineering  (SME)  [34-37].  SME  incorporates  an  iterative  and incremental  design  process  that  emphasizes  the  evaluation  of  method  modifications  to validate  fitness  for  use  and  value  outcome.

Maturity  assessment  and  improvement  for  digital  PM  in  municipalities  is  a  concrete engineering  scenario  that  requires  situational  customization  of  a  more  general  standard method.  Consequently,  we  aim  to  engineer  a  situational  method  for  the  given  scenario that  integrates  a  conceptual  maturity  model  as  tool  [38]  for  providing  practical  guidance for  assessing  and  improving  the  maturity  level  of  digital  project  management  in  municipalities.  Furthermore,  we  aim  to  contribute  to  the  method  base  of  maturity  models  in support  of  further  developments  of  other  situational  maturity  methods.

The  first  step  of  our  engineering  process,  illustrated  in  Fig.  1,  comprises  characterizing  the  situation  by  accumulating  domain  knowledge  on  digital  project  management  in municipalities.  A  situation  is  'characterised  by  a  number  of  factors  that  influence  or  are being  influenced  by  a  method  fragment'  [35].  Method  fragments  are  the  building  blocks of  situational  methods,  defined  as  'coherent  pieces  of  IS  development  methods'  [32]. The  fragments  can  be  either  process-focused  or  product-focused,  and  both  subtypes  can be  combined  to  form  composite  method  chunks  [35].  The  initial  knowledge  about  the situation  was  acquired  by  conducting  both  a  literature  review  and  expert  interviews.

Fig. 1. Situational  method  engineering  process  for  constructing  ECoProMD.

## 3.2 Literature Review and Interviews

To  gain  a  profound  understanding  of  the  situation,  we  performed  a  narrative  literature review  [39]  with  a  mixed  scope  on  research  outcomes,  methods,  and  practices  or  applications  following  an  iterative  process.  For  the  initial  search  we  used  the  literature  databases Google  Scholar,  Semantic  Scholar,  Bielefeld  Academic  Search  Engine  (BASE),  and  the Open  Research  Knowledge  Graph  (ORKG)  with  the  search  term  '('project  management'  AND  'maturity')  AND  ('municipal'  OR  'local  government'  OR  'public')'.  We

selected  relevant  papers  by  screening  title  and  abstract  and  continued  with  backward and  forward  searches.  From  the  review  results,  we  collected  influencing  or  influenced factors  like  stakeholders,  actor  roles,  organizational  structures,  practices  and  processes, application  systems,  challenges,  and  success  factors  [40].

Expert  interviews  were  another  method  we  used  to  collect  empirical  data  for  accumulating  knowledge  about  the  domain.  For  the  interviews,  we  selected  seven  people from  different  organizations  because  of  their  domain-specific  knowledge  displayed  by their  organizational  role.  Of  the  seven  people,  six  work  for  municipal  organizations  and one  for  a  state  administration,  where  the  person  coordinates  projects  with  municipal partners.  Table  1  gives  an  overview  of  the  interviewees  with  their  characteristics.

All  interviews  were  conducted  as  semi-structured  conversations  based  on  a  standardized  guideline.  After  a  short  introduction  and  some  person-related  questions,  we  asked for  the  state  of  PM,  best  practices  in  the  organization,  and  success  factors,  followed  by questions  on  requirements  for  a  PM3  and  further  issues  from  the  interviewee's  view, before  closing  with  a  request  for  feedback.  The  recordings  or  protocols  were  transcribed and  went  through  a  qualitative  content  analysis  following  [41]  using  the  software  tool MAXQDA. During our research  process,  we  performed  a  series  of  three  interview  rounds from  June  to  October  2024,  starting  with  requirements-focused  interviews  and  ending with  two  rounds  of  evaluative  interviews.  In  the  third  round,  two  interviewees  were  not available,  resulting  in  a  total  of  19  interviews.  The  interview  duration  was  in  the  first and  second  round  between  60  min  and  1h  50  min,  in  the  third  round  50  min  on  average.

## 3.3 Iterative Engineering Process

After  characterizing  the  situation,  the  process  continues  with  iterative  engineering  steps. The knowledge base provides requirements that are used for selecting appropriate method  fragments  from  the  method  base  guided  by  the  individual  design  goal  and  design principles  [25,  42].  Because  of  our  focus  on  high  usability  for  practice,  our  method  base was created from both international best practice standards  for  project  management maturity  assessment  and  published  maturity  models  from  academic  literature.  Of  the many  existing  best  practice  models,  we  selected  the  Capability  Maturity  Model  Integration  (CMMI)  as  the  'mother'  of  all  capability  maturity  models  [14]  and  three  project management  focused  models  with  relevance  for  public  administration  according  to  the expert  interviews  (see  Table  2).

Table 2. Selected  maturity  models  forming  the  method  base.

| Short name   | Name                                                       | Creator   |   Last update |
|--------------|------------------------------------------------------------|-----------|---------------|
| CMMI         | Capability Maturity Model Integration                      | ISACA     |          2023 |
| IPMA Delta   | IPMA Delta                                                 | IPMA      |          2021 |
| OPM3         | Organizational Project Management Maturity Model           | PMI       |          2013 |
| P3M3         | Portfolio, Programme and Project Management Maturity Model | Axelos    |          2015 |

(ISACA: Information Systems Audit and Control Association, IPMA: International Project Management  Association,  PMI:  Project  Management  Institute).

The  next  step  is  selecting  method  fragments  from  the  method  base  that  meet  the specific  requirements  of  municipal  project  management  according  to  the  knowledge base  for  inclusion  into  the  new  situational  method  (e.g.,  compliance  with  regulations and  laws,  transparency,  and  budget  control).  Also,  more  general  quality  criteria  (e.g., reliability,  applicability,  user-friendliness)  emphasized  by  the  municipal  experts  were considered.  Other  options for the design decision are the exclusion  of  inappropriate fragments  or  the  adaptation  of  fragments  in  the  next  step.

For  the  evaluation  of  the  assembled  method,  we  conducted  two  rounds  of  semistructured  interviews  asking  the  seven  experts  for  detailed  feedback  on  the  method's strengths and weaknesses.  This feedback  was  used for further improvements  of  the method  in  the  following  iteration.

## 4 Specific Requirements of Municipalities

When  developing  the  maturity  model,  the  specific  requirements  of  the  target  group  had to  be  considered  to  ensure  its  practical  applicability  and  effectiveness.  The  following design  premises  emerged  from  the  results  of  the  literature  review  and  the  findings  of  the first  round  of  expert  interviews  regarding  the  specific  framework  conditions,  challenges, and  success  factors  for  digitalization  projects  in  public  administration.

- 1) Low-threshold access and flexibility. Municipalities  in  Germany  vary  greatly  in terms  of  size,  resources,  and  digital  maturity.  The  maturity  model  must  reflect  the  organizational  structures  and  processes  of  the  municipal  administration  and  accommodate the  diverse  starting  conditions  and  capabilities  [E5].  This  includes  clear,  understandable language  [E1],  simple  application  mechanisms,  and  a  flexible  evaluation  system.  The model  is  intended  to  enable  municipalities  with  scarce  resources  to  realistically  assess the  status  quo  of  their  PM  and  derive  concrete,  implementable  development  steps  without  the  need  for  extensive  prior  knowledge  or  specialized  external  support  [E3-6].  The maturity  levels,  criteria,  and  evaluation  scales  must  therefore  be  formulated  in  a  practical and  easily  accessible  manner  to  ensure  broad  application.
- 2) Time required and complexity. Time  is  a  crucial  factor  [E2].  The  time  required  by organizations  to  apply  the  maturity  model  should  be  as  short  as  possible.  Conducting the  assessment  must  be  efficient  and  time  saving  [E6],  particularly  for  municipalities with  limited  human  resources.  This  requires  a  compact  structure,  clear  questions,  and a  clear  presentation  of  the  results  [E6].  The  model  should  be  'translated  as  practically as  possible  and  must  not  be  overly  complex'  (all  quotations  from  the  interviews  are translated  from  German  and  redacted)  [E4].  The  goal  is  for  municipalities  to  quickly assess  the  maturity  of  their  PM  and  derive  concrete  recommendations  for  action  without having  to  undergo  extensive  analysis  processes.
- 3) Focus on single project management. The  model  should  consider  the  specific  context of single digitalization projects. These projects are characterized  by  high  complexity,  technological  dynamics,  and  interdisciplinarity.  The  maturity  model  must  be able  to  reflect  these  factors  by  addressing  key  aspects  such  as  stakeholder,  change,  and risk  management,  as  well  as  digital  technologies  and  work  practices.  The  model  should place  strong  emphasis  on  operational  individual  PM,  as  this  enables  low-threshold  entry, especially  for  small  municipalities  [E3],  and  supports  the  successful  implementation  of projects.  The  model  must  therefore  provide  concrete  and  action-oriented  criteria  for  the evaluation  and  further  development  of  individual  projects.
- 4)  Suitability  for  self-assessment. It should  be possible for the parties involved  to collect the data for maturity assessment  independently,  i.e. without the  involvement of external third parties (e.g., consultants) [E3]. The  main  reasons  cited for this are expected  resource constraints (especially time and staff). For the  implementation  of self-assessments,  standardized  questionnaires  have  proven  their  worth  in  practice  [23]. This  requirement  correlates  with  the  low-threshold  access  and  the  time  required,  as  the maturity  assessment  can  be  conducted  on  this  basis  according  to  a  simple,  generally understandable  scheme,  eliminating  the  need  for  extensive  coordination  with  external stakeholders.
- 5) Consideration of organizational context. Since  PM  is  embedded  in  an  organizational  context  and  interfaces  exist  between  the  project  organization  and  the  line  organization,  the  model  must  also  take  into  account  corresponding  interactions  between  the projects  and  the  line  organization  in  the  evaluation  criteria  (e.g.,  organizational  framework  conditions  such  as  strategic  specifications  and  goals  of  the  line  organization  as well  as  interfaces)  [E1,  E3].

- 6) Tool support. The  applying  municipal  organizations  should  be  guided  through  maturity  assessment  according  to  a  concrete,  uniform  system.  Therefore,  maturity  level  measurement  and  assessment  should  be  supported  electronically  wherever  possible  [E7]. By  providing  a  digital  tool  (e.g.,  as  a  web-based  application),  a  fast,  automated,  and multi-layered  evaluation  (including  a  dashboard  view)  should  be  realized  [E1].
- 7)  Continuous  maturity  assessment. Finally, it must be ensured that the maturity model  not  only  allows  for  a  static  assessment  but  also  serves  as  a  tool  for  continuous improvement  [26].  The  model  should  therefore  be  designed  in  such  a  way  that  it  supports the development  of  digitalization projects over time and creates incentives for ongoing  optimization  [E2,  E3,  E6].  For  this  purpose,  basic  specifications  for  the  establishment  of  an  organizational  routine  (e.g.,  definition  of  responsibilities  and  specification of  evaluation  cycles)  must  be  made.

These  requirements  form  the  basis  for  the  development  of  the  maturity  model  and ensure  that  it  meets  the  specific  needs  of  municipal  administration  in  Germany  and  offers a  high  level  of  practical  benefit.

## 5 The ECoProMD Artifact

We  defined  four  maturity  levels  for  a  differentiated  view  of  PM  maturity  in  municipal authorities  and  institutions.  Five  dimensions  are  used  to  structure  PM  in  terms  of  content, which  are  assessed  based  on  specific  individual  criteria.  The  required  data  is  collected using  a  questionnaire-based  self-assessment.  A  five-point  Likert  scale  is  used  for  the evaluation. This section provides an  overview of the basic model  elements and the evaluation  system.

## 5.1 Model Perspective

The  ECoProMD  model  describes  the  maturity  of  PM  according  to  the  four  maturity levels  listed  in  Table  3.

Table 3. ECoProMD  maturity  levels.

| Maturity level   | Characteristics                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
|------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 1) Initial       | • PM practices are informal, unstructured and ad-hoc. No standardized processes or methods exist • Project success depends heavily on individuals and their individual skills • There is little organizational support for PM • Projects have a limited focus on strategic goals |

( continued )

Table 3. ( continued )

| Maturity level   | Characteristics                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 2) Defined       | • Fundamentally defined PM processes exist and initial approaches to standardizing terminology, methods and tools have been made • Project planning tasks such as target definition, resource planning and work breakdown structure are partially implemented • Basic structures and roles for PM have been established • PM knowledge is beginning to be anchored in parts of the organization |
| 3) Standardized  | • PM processes and methods are applied uniformly and as standard in projects throughout the organization • Clear structures, roles and responsibilities in PM exist • Processes for all PM phases (initiation, planning, implementation, controlling, and closure) are established • Projects are widely aligned with strategic objectives                                                      |
| 4) Governed      | • PM is firmly anchored in the organization and is developed proactively and continuously • PM methods are flexibly adapted to the respective project requirements • PM skills are developed throughout the organization • PM is an integral part of the organizational strategy                                                                                                                |

Maturity  level  2  (defined)  represents  the  baseline,  i.e.,  the  minimum  requirements for  professional  PM  are  met  when  this  level  is  reached.  It  should  at  least  be  achieved and  therefore  represents  the  minimum  target.  The  model  thus  provides  basic  orientation, particularly  for  municipalities  with  little  or  no  PM  experience,  and  removes  significant barriers  to  entry.  In  contrast,  maturity  level  3  (standardized)  represents  the  normal  target, i.e.,  when  this  level  is  reached,  the  organization  meets  all  the  basic  requirements  for professional  PM.  This  maturity  level  aims  to  provide  an  incentive  for  continuous  further development  beyond  the  minimum  level.

## PM Dimensions and Criteria

Based  on  the  analysis  of  existing  PM3s  and  taking  into  account  the  specific  requirements and  best  practices  from  the  expert  interviews,  the  five  PM  dimensions  with  according criteria  presented  in  Table  4  were  defined  for  the  ECoProMD  model.

## Data Collection and Evaluation

For  collecting  the  required  data  for  an  assessment,  a  questionnaire  was  designed,  which queries  all  ECoProMD  criteria  dimensions  and  also  considers  the  requirements  from the  expert  interviews.  The  questionnaire  is  divided  into  five  sections  according  to  the dimensions,  with  a  total  of  40  questions  covering  the  individual  criteria.

As  part  of  the  questionnaire-based  self-assessment,  the  degree  of  implementation within  the  organization  is  determined  for  each  criterion  by  the  respondents'  subjective assessment  using  a  five-point  Likert  scale:

0 - does not apply at all, 1 - applies to a small extent, 2 - partially applies, 3 - largely applies, 4 - fully applies.

Table 4. ECoProMD  dimensions  and  criteria.

| Dimension                    | Criteria                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
|------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 1) Strategic alignment       | • Alignment of projects with organizational goals (interface to project portfolio management) • Development and alignment with a digitalization strategy • Prioritization of digitalization projects • Long-term resource and capacity planning • Benefit and value orientation of projects • Sustainable integration of project results • Continuous monitoring of the project environment • Continuous improvement of the organization's PM approach |
| 2) Processes, methods &tools | • Project initiation and target definition • Project planning (resource, cost and project structure) • Project implementation and controlling (reporting, change control, quality assurance) • Project closure and evaluation (lessons learned, knowledge transfer) • Selection and application of suitable PM methods, PM software, and collaboration tools • Project information management (incl. documentation)                                    |
| 3) Digital competencies      | • Methodological knowledge in digital PM • Basic IT knowledge in the project context • Information security and data privacy in the project context • Understanding of digital technologies and trends • Planning and organizational competencies • Leadership and team management competencies • Further training &competence development • Continuous learning and knowledge sharing                                                                 |
| 4) Structure &governance     | • Definition of project roles and responsibilities • Establishment and effectiveness of a central PM office (PMO) • Integration of project work into the line organization • Operational risk management and control • Effective resource allocation and control • Budget planning and management • Supplier and contract management • Decision-making structures and escalation channels                                                              |
| 5) Culture &change           | • Support from higher management level • Acceptance of PM methods • Error culture and willingness to learn • Promotion of innovation and openness to new approaches • Stakeholder management and communication • Dealing with change and resistance • Involving employees in change processes • Promoting teamwork and cross-departmental collaboration (forming interdisciplinary teams)                                                              |

The  five-point  scale  allows  a  differentiated  assessment  by  the  respondents  and  is fully  transferable  in  terms  of  maturity  levels  by  means  of  scoring.  For  this  purpose,  each scale  entry  is  assigned  a  score  from  0  to  4  points  (does  not  apply  at  all = 0  points,  applies to  a  small  extent = 1  point,  etc.).

To  evaluate  the  questionnaire,  the  average  of  all  ratings  is  first  calculated  for  each dimension.  The  overall  average  is  then  calculated  from  the  mean  value  of  all  dimensions. The  maturity  level  is  determined  on  this  basis  using  the  following  range  of  points:

0-0.99 pts.: initial, 1-1.99 pts.: defined, 2-2.99 pts.: standardized, 3-4 pts.: governed.

Concerning  the  data  evaluation,  it  was  required  to  enable  a  differentiated  understanding  of  the  data  (per  dimension)  and  to  support  quick  and  easy  graphical  visualization. A  spider  web  diagram  is  suitable  for  this  purpose.  The  evaluation  results  can  thus  be viewed  in  direct  comparison.  However,  this  representation  does  not  allow  any  statement about  specific  weak  points  or  improvement  potentials.  A  detailed  evaluation  of  the  individual  criteria  is  therefore  also  necessary.  A  bullet  chart  is  suitable  for  obtaining  a  quick overview  of  the  status  of  all  individual  criteria  in  all  dimensions.  Thus,  the  maturity  levels achieved  for  each  individual  criterion  can  be  specifically  tracked  and  compared  with  the desired  target  state.  This  detailed  view  also  provides  clues  as  to  where  strengths  (individual  criterion  with  a  high  level  of  maturity)  and  potential  for  improvement  (individual criterion with  a low  level of maturity)  lie. In  addition,  detailed  analysis  also  enables the  transparent  presentation  of  progress  as  part  of  the  continuous  maturity  assessment. Based  on  the  respective  target  status  (e.g.,  normal  target  maturity  level  3),  the  degree of fulfillment  or progress  (ratio  of  achieved  point  value  to  target  point value)  can  be determined  and  displayed.

## 5.2 Method Perspective

Since  a  static  approach  neglects  the  continuous  development  of  competencies  and  the associated  evolutionary  progress  of  maturity  in  constantly  changing  organizations,  ECoProMD  aims  to  provide  recommendations  for  establishing  maturity  measurement  as  a continuous  organizational  routine  in  line  with  [26].  Two  factors  are  particularly  important  for  this:  the  definition  of  a  role  responsible  for  implementation  and  the  definition  of schedules  and  recurring  triggers  for  tracking  capabilities  [26].  Due  to  the  very  different starting  situations  in  the  individual  municipalities,  the  only  recommendation  made  at this  point  is  to  define  a  role  responsible  for  maturity  assessment.  For  the  ECoProMD model,  we  defined  a  five-step  evaluation  cycle,  which  is  illustrated  in  Fig.  2  together with  the  maturity  levels  and  dimensions.

For the initiation, certain decision parameters must be defined by the  organization. These  include  the requirements  of  the target organization  and  the definition of the  assessment  objective.  The  design  objectives  of  the  ECoProMD  model  provide  an initial  orientation.  In  the  second  step  (analyze  &amp;  assign),  the  current  maturity  level  is determined  using  the  questionnaire  provided.  The  result  provides  the  organization  with a  differentiated  overview  of  the  strengths  and  potential  for  improvement  for  each  dimension  or  individual  criterion.  Subsequently,  improvement  measures  can  be  defined  and prioritized  based  on  the  current  maturity  level  and  the  organization's  goals.  ECoProMD is  intended  to  provide  concrete  catalogs  of  measures  and  best  practices  for  this  in  the

Fig. 2. Integrated  perspective  on  the  ECoProMD  model  and  method.

<!-- image -->

future.  In  the  fourth  step,  the  defined  measures  are  implemented.  The  final  phase  checks the  outcome  and  impact  of  the  executed  measures.  It  also  ensures  that  the  maturity  model is  used  continuously  and  initiates  the  next  assessment  cycle.  Based  on  the  expert  statements,  a  cyclical  application  of  the  ECoProMD  model  within  a  period  of  24  months  is recommended.

## 6 Discussion and Conclusion

The  ECoProM-D  maturity  model  and  method  provide  a  compact  instrument  specifically  tailored  to  the  requirements  of  digital  PM  for  municipals  in  the  context  of  digital transformation.  With  its  integrated  approach  and  the  provision  of  a  standardized  questionnaire  with  a  multi-level  answer  and  evaluation  scale  corresponding  to  the  maturity levels,  the  model  enables  a  differentiated  determination  of  the  maturity  level  of  digital project  management  in  municipal  administrations.

Beyond  the  focus  on  municipalities,  the  model  is  characterized  by  the  integration of the  model  and  the  method  perspective.  The  integrated  model/method  perspective

on maturity assessment  contributes  to  the  design  knowledge  on  maturity  models  by demonstrating  the appropriateness of situational method  engineering  for developing new  domain-specific  maturity  models.  Furthermore,  the  emphasis  of  the  method  character  follows  the  recently  formulated  claim  for  continuous  maturity  assessment  [26]. Since  digital  transformation  is  known  to  inflict  frequent  and  extensive  change  on  organizations,  digital  PM  needs  to  incorporate  continuous  improvement  to  be  capable  of handling  change  successfully.  As  digitalization  projects  adopt  iterative  and  incremental development  processes  like  Scrum,  the  assessment  of  digital  PM  maturity  must  also adapt  to  these  new  requirements  through  a  shift  from  one-time  initiatives  to  a  continuous  process.  This  position  is  also  supported  by  the  concept  of  business  process  maturity based  on  a  lifecycle  view  of  business  processes  [43].

In  comparison  to  other  PM3s,  it  stands  out  that  ECoProMD  features  only  four  maturity  levels,  while  many  other  maturity  models  offer  five  or  more  levels.  While  more levels may  enable  a more  precise maturity assessment,  the restriction to four levels was  a  deliberate  design  decision  explicitly  demanded  by  the  involved  experts  to  reduce complexity  and  enhance  practicability.  Like  the  rest  of  ECoProMD,  the  effect  of  this decision  has  not  been  evaluated  in  the  field  yet.  It  is  one  of  the  main  limitations  at  this point  that  the  artifact  was  validated  with  a  formative  evaluation  and  a  relatively  small sample  of  experts.  Regarding  the  method  part  of  ECoProMD  the  guidance  on  performing  an  assessment  is  elaborated  in  more  detail  than  the  support  on  how  to  develop  and implement  concrete  measures  to  reach  the  next  maturity  level.  Furthermore,  the  national perspective  on  German  municipalities  may  require  adjustments  before  using  the  model in  other  countries.  To  overcome  these  and  other  limitations,  further  empirical  research on  effectiveness  and  efficiency  in  municipal  contexts  of  different  sizes  and  types  (e.g., district  administrations)  is  required.  Related  research  directions  include  the  development of  a  digital  tool  for  applying  ECoProMD  and  investigating  the  acceptance  of  the  model by  various  municipal  stakeholders.
