However,  although  most  consider  access  enough  for  the  type  of  use  they  perceive  as needed,  access  cannot  be  regarded  as  meaningful  [5].  Women  face  limitations  and  difficulties,  from  difficulty  acquiring  a  connection  to  unstable  signals  and  limited  memory space  on  devices.  Juliana  and  Camila  habitually  delete  governmental  apps  from  their devices  after  use,  as  they  don't  have  enough  memory  space  to  keep  them.  Gabriela,  a single  mother  of  a  child  with  a  cognitive  disability,  relies  on  neighbors  or  solidarity  of local  internet  providers  to  be  able  to  have  a  fixed  internet  connection  at  home,  as  she cannot  afford  either  fixed  or  postpaid  4G:

'…  money  is  not  enough  to  pay  for  the  internet  …there  is  no  money  left  over  for anything  ...  but  everywhere  I  go,  there  is  a  neighbor  who  allows  me  to  use  [their wifi]… '  (Gabriela)

From  the  perspective  of  autonomous  use,  whether  digitally  excluded  women  managed  to  access  digital  social  services  through  the  help  of  intermediaries,  this  happened with psychological  consequences,  as  there  is  a  bitter feeling of not being  able to do things  by  oneself  anymore:

' I  feel  terrible  …  because  you  go  in  one  place,  you  can't  do  it  [access  service], you  go  in  another  [the  same  happens]…,  because  this  …  had  to  be  released  for the  elderly  to  be  able  to  get  things  [social  benefits] '  (Sofia)

## 4.2 Statement 2: Ambivalent Experiences Shaped by Identities

Participants'  experiences  with  digital  welfare  are  ambivalent.  On  the  positive  pole,  terms such  as  satisfaction,  being  taken  care  of,  and  support  describe  the  feelings  associated with  digital  social  policies.  Terrible,  complex,  impossible,  and  bureaucratic  are  words employed  to  describe  the  experience  on  the  negative  pole.  Frequently,  both  feelings  are present  in  the  reasoning  of  the  same  participant,  reinforcing  the  ambivalence  of  digital

welfare  in  the  experiences  of  women  in  M'Boi  Mirim.  Larissa's  experience  with  digital welfare  symbolizes  the  middle  of  this  spectrum:

' At  the  same  time  that  they  help,  at  the  same  time  they  drive  us  crazy,  like,  I  think it's  half,  half,  because  yes,  it  helps  a  lot,  but  also  when  there  is  a  problem,  to  solve it  is  even  more  a  hell  of  a  bureaucracy '  (Larissa)

Despite  the  homogeneous  group  of  women  interviewed  regarding  gender  identity, class,  color/race,  and  geographical  region,  different  experiences  were  shaped  mainly  by markers  of  difference  such  as  age,  level  of  education,  and  family  configuration.  The design of digital social services also played a role.  Sub-statements  presented  below explore  these  aspects.

Digital Welfare as a Form of Disablement and Loss of Autonomy. Aged  women with  low  levels  of  education  were  mostly  digitally  excluded,  and  this  exclusion  was  felt deeper  when  there  was  no  member  of  the  family  to  help,  as  it  is  for  Sofia,  who  lives  by herself.

' I  don't  know  how  to  use  it  because  I  have  little  education,  and  I  don't  know  how to  use  anything,  not  an  app,  nor  the  internet,  anything...  I  only  know  how  to  use this  [showing  WhatsApp  on  her  phone];  my  phone  must  have  internet,  but  I  don't know  … '  (Sofia)

This  feeling  of  not  being  capable  is  related  to  a  common  fear  of  doing  something irreversibly  wrong  or  falling  into  a  scam  with  severe  consequences,  such  as  losing  their money.  Valentina  exemplifies  this  concern  by  showing  during  the  interview  a  message she  had  just  received  from  an  unknown  person  offering  her  consigned  credit.

These  women  rely  primarily  on  others  to  use  the  internet  and  access  social  digital services.  However,  the  use  by  proxy  [14]  is  problematic  as  it  subjects  them  to  the  availability  and  goodwill  of  intermediaries,  such  as  family  or  community  members,  bonds that  may  be  hard  to  substitute  in  their  absence.

'…  I  can't;  I  need  someone's  help;  it's  so  that  if  one  day  I  move  away  from  here or  Beth  [church  volunteer  who  helps  her]  leaves  here,  I  don't  know  what  to  do ' (Sofia)

When  there  is  no  volunteer  to  help,  it  is  necessary  to  resort  to  a  paid  intermediary  or, if  it  is  a  matter  of  public  service,  visit  a  Descomplica  unit  in  Sªo  Paulo,  which  is  a  service center  to  assist  citizens  with  technology,  among  other  services.  Sofia,  for  example,  pays an  internet  cafe  every  month  to  print  her  telecom  bill,  which  she  no  longer  receives  on paper,  at  her  address.

Intermediation  of  digital  services  also  increases  the  exposure  of  personal  data  and risk,  as  women  may  not  always  be  aware  of  what  others  are  doing  in  their  names.  In  this scenario,  trust  in  other  people  stands  out  as  a  fundamental  element:

' I  don't  do  it  ...  They  [sons]  do  it  ...  sometimes  he  [referring  to  one  of  her  sons] looks  at  my  salary,  ...  manages  my  retirement  … '  (Valentina)

However,  satisfaction  with  using  digital  technology  through  intermediaries  differs among  them.  Sofia,  for  example,  was  very  unsatisfied  as  digitalization  undermined  her autonomy  to  solve  her  problems  independently  and  to  interact  with  government  bodies and  private  companies.  This  dependence  is  frustrating  for  her,  while  Valentina,  even  if  it represents  a  loss  of  autonomy,  prefers  someone  to  do  whatever  she  needs  so  she  doesn't have  to  go  to  public  offices  in  person.

' ...  I'd  rather  he  [son]  makes  it  [appointment  with  the  doctor  using  the  Agenda Fácil  app];  I'm  already  tired,  with  my  old  legs  and  climbing  all  this  …  [reference to the slope near  her house  and  how  it would  be  difficult to  walk  through  it] ' (Valentina)

Not  being  able  to  use  it  directly,  feeling  disempowered,  or  losing  autonomy  seem  to contribute  to  making  transformative  good  digital  changes  underperceived  or  undervalued by  some  participants.  Valentina  says,  ' …  for  me,  not  much  has  changed ,' as  her  son does  everything  she  needs.  Even  when  participants  are  aware  of  significant  changes, improvements  may  be  unperceived  or  undervalued,  as  in  the  case  of  Sofia.

Annually,  retired individuals  were  required  to provide  proof  of life at a  physical INSS  agency;  however,  this  process  is  now  fully  automated  in  most  cases  through  the cross-referencing  of  databases.  While  Sofia  is  aware  that  she  no  longer  has  to  provide proof  of  life,  she  doesn't  seem  to  recognize  it  as  a  positive  experience;  for  her,  digital welfare  has  brought  only  frustrating  and  disempowering  feelings  rather  than  positive changes.

Digital Welfare as a Means of Empowerment and Fulfilling Citizenship. The  more young  women  interviewed  represent  another  facet  of  experience  dealing  with  the  digital world.  With  varying  degrees,  they  are  all  direct  users  of  digital  social  policies  and  other digital  technologies,  such  as  digital  private  banks,  music  apps,  online  classes,  streaming services,  and  social  networks.  Feeling  secure,  taken  care  of,  and  welcomed  are  frequently mentioned  in  these  cases,  as  exemplified  by  Camila,  who  works  online  from  home  and is  a  mother  to  a  young  child.

' I  feel  very  graced,  let's  put  it  this  way  …  it's  free,  it's  public,  and  it  works!  These are  three  things  you  usually  can't  fit  in  the  same  sentence  … '  (Camila)

Juliana,  a  young  woman  with  a  physical  disability,  explained  her  contact  with  digital social  policies  had  mainly  to  do  with  circumstances  that  forced  her  to  go  digital.  However, she  felt  a  sense  of  empowerment  from  using  it  and  perceived  digital  public  services  as an  opportunity  to  save  time  and  reduce  her  commuting.

Digital Welfare as Fight, Anxiety, and Humiliation. Sometimes,  the  experience  is also  described  as  frustrating,  terrible,  and  impossible,  fostering  feelings  of  exclusion  and anxiety.  The  digitalization  of  CRAS  appointment  scheduling  is  a  prominent  example,  and it  is  unanimously  described  as  challenging  and  almost  impossible  by  all  the  interviewees who  needed  it.

CRAS,  along  with  the  INSS,  is  one of Brazil's  most  important  social  protection units.  While  the  INSS  is  responsible  for  retirement,  pensions,  unemployment  security, and  payment  of  BPC  for  people  with  disabilities,  among  others,  the  CRAS  is  accountable

for  the  reception  of  all  other  social  needs,  including  non-contributory  assistance  such as  the  Bolsa  Família,  the  national  conditional  cash  transfer  program  for  people  leaving  in  poverty  or  extreme  poverty.  Similarly,  the  Unified  Registry  for  Social  Programs (CadÚnico)  is  the  most  critical  registration  that  citizens  entitled  to  social  benefits  and cash  transfers  must  fill  in  to  be  eligible  to  access  them,  such  as  the  milk  benefit  (Leve Leite).  The  CRAS  are  the  units  responsible  for  filling  in  these  registries.

The  change  in  CRAS  scheduling  in  the  city  of  Sªo  Paulo  is  emblematic  for  most participants,  as  its  digitalization,  transitioning  from  in-person  to  online  (or  telephone) scheduling,  became  a  gatekeeper  to  the  service.  Although  there  are  many  CRAS  offices around the city, they now  refuse face-to-face contact unless it has been previously scheduled  virtually.  Camila  explains  her  frustration  very  clearly.

- ' …  I  get  very  upset  because  it's  a  service  that  we  are  entitled  to,  that  is  not  difficult to  have  physical  access,  but  what  makes  it  impossible  for  us  to  have  physical  access is  the  digital  … '  (Camila)

Updating  CadÚnico,  in  this  scenario,  became  a  source  of  anxiety,  as  it  depends  on the  online  scheduling  of  CRAS.  Keeping  the  CadÚnico  updated,  including  children's school  attendance  and  vaccination  information,  is  a  major  concern  for  women  who  rely more  deeply  on  social  benefits,  as  the  expiration  or  outdated  information  implies  the suspension  of  their  provision.

- '…  That's  what  they  say,  it  doesn't  block,  ...  but  if  you  stay  for  two  months  without updating  the  registration  ...  they  block  it '  (Gabriela)

Larissa  seems  to  suggest  that it would  be  better if  she  could  complete  the  entire process  of  CadÚnico  actualization  online,  as  scheduling  an  appointment  at  CRAS  is almost  impossible,  showing  a  propensity  to  deeper  digitalization.

- ' ...  you  have  to  re-register  for  Bolsa  Família,  to  update,  [and]  it's  a  sacrifice  ...  to schedule  because  you  don't  do  any  of  this  over  the  internet,  we  can  only  schedule [the  service],  so  for  you  to  schedule  it  is  a  damn  bureaucracy  because  as  much as  they  have  vacancies,  they  don't  release  them,  so  you  have  to  stay  there 24  h watching  to  see  if  a  spot  is  released  ... '  (Larissa)

For all that, attempts to schedule are described by participants as a struggle, as something  you  have  to  fight  for.

- ' …  They  say  that  there  is  no  more  vacancy,  that  it  has  already  been  completed, and  you  are  in  this  agony,  see,  it's  terrible...  You  keep  fighting;  some  people  get up  at  dawn  to  call  to  see  if  they  can  schedule  it '  (Sofia)

It  looks  like  the  traditional  daybreak  queues  in  many  public  services  in  Brazil,  a  symbol  of  precariousness,  have  been  removed  to  people's  homes,  where  they  can  struggle alone,  hidden  from  public  scrutiny,  eliminating  pressure  from  public  service  to  the  individuals  who  need  to  deal  by  themselves  with  an  internet  connection,  devices,  and  virtual public  encounters.  Humiliation  and  begging  are  words  that  appear  in  some  interviews when  the  CRAS  in  Sªo  Paulo  city  is  mentioned.

' …  I  cried  inside  the  CRAS  …  I  cried  like  a  child  there,  begging,  and  they  said  I couldn't,  that  I  should  …  go  home  and  call  [to  schedule  an  appointment] '  (Sofia)

In  the  case  of  CRAS  scheduling,  digitalization  promoted  an  inversion  where  entitled citizens,  such  as  disadvantaged  mothers  and  retired  women,  must  beg  for  something  that the  government  should  assure.

Digital Welfare as Both Information Empowerment and Disempowerment. Access to information  is another theme  frequently  mentioned  by  participants, and it is also mentioned  in  an  ambivalent  way.  On  the  one  hand,  the  possibility  of  checking  information independently  empowers  women,  allowing  them  to  be  more  aware  of  important  data  and avoid  waiting  in  line  at  a  public  agency.  One  of  the  participants,  for  instance,  could  see in  the  app  that  the  attendant  had  incorrectly  filed  the  date  of  birth  of  one  of  her  children, so  she  took  action  to  correct  it  before  incurring  any  loss  in  benefits.

Trust  in  information  is  another  issue.  Even  when  information  is  available  online, many  participants  still  rely  on  offline  interactions  to  verify  the  accuracy  and  reliability of  the  app  information.  More  information  is  readily  available,  saving  commuting  time, but  distrust  persists,  prompting  people  to  continue  going  to  offices  anyway.

Juliana:  ' It  was  easier  because  we  had  most  of  the  information  we  wanted  to  know there  [in  the  app]  …  You  didn't  have  to  leave  the  house,  right?  To  the  bank  ... '

Interviewer:  ' But  did  she  [her  mother]  go  to  the  bank  afterward?

'

Juliana:  ' Yes,  it's  because  she  still  had  doubts,  right?  Then,  she  wanted  to  be  sure if  that  was  the  case  ... '

On the other hand, they wish to have more detailed information, especially concerning  benefits  cuts  or  reductions  in  the  amounts.

' No,  there's  no  explanation;  it  doesn't  show;  if  it  gets  blocked  or  canceled,  they don't  give  you  justification,  then,  if  you  go  up  to  CRAS,  you  don't  solve  it  there either,  they  don't  give  you  any  information  …  They  don't  have  it,  …  or  I  don't know  why  [they  don't  give  the  information],  because  I  don't  understand  either ' (Larissa)

Offline  service,  however,  seems  worse  than  ever  in  the  participants'  speech,  as  they feel  that  frontline  workers  are  not  prepared  to  act  under  the  new  digital  logic.

' Sometimes  you  go  looking  for  information  about  something,  that  person  doesn't even  know  what  we're  talking  about…  you  see  people  that  aren't  ready  to  be  in the  place  yet,  but  who  are  there  anyway,  but  without  knowing  anything,  then  … you  feel  horrible;  I  think  that's  what  is  missing,  it's  a  lot  of  training  ... '  (Larissa)

In  a  scenario  where  information  is  insufficient  and  frontline  workers  are  untrained, inconsistencies  and  malfunctions  become  very  difficult  to  resolve,  generating  new  opacities  in  service  delivery  and  requiring  people  to  embark  on  a  journey  in  search  of  solutions. Gabriela,  for  instance,  whose  child  was  entitled  to  the  milk  benefit,  wasn't  receiving  it. She  took  more  than  nine  months,  peregrinating  with  her  child  from  one  public  agency to  another,  with  no  one  being  able  to  resolve  the  issue,  before  finally  discovering  that

her  file  had  never  been  updated  in  the  system,  a  task  that  school  frontline  workers  were supposed  to  handle.

## 4.3 Statement 3: Reinforcement of Gender Roles and Burdens

Maternity  constantly  appears  as  an  identity  that  drives  the  use  of  digital  government,  as  it obliges  disadvantaged  mothers,  who  are  usually  the  default  reference  for  social  services in  Brazil,  to  navigate  various  governmental  apps  from  different  levels  of  government and  for  children  of  different  ages.

' If  it's  related  to  my  child,  it's  always  me….  He  [partner]  …  executes  …  but  for that  to  happen,  I  must  pull  my  strings  and  manage,…  see  what  is  needed,  what documentation  needs  to  be  taken '  (Camila)

In  this  sense,  being  the  reference  for  the  children  sums  up  the  burden  of  reproductive and  care labor.  Larissa,  responsible  for  five  children,  expresses  the  physical  and emotional  distress  provoked  by  maternity  and  unpaid  care  labor.

' …  today  here  I  am,  having  to  take  care  of  the  house,  freaking  out  …  Being  a mother  is  not  easy  for  anyone;  …  we  get  tired  physically  and  emotionally,  we  get exhausted,  and  there  comes  the  point  where  you  don't  even  know  who  you  are anymore '  (Larissa)

Larissa,  who  used  to  take  the  night  shift  at  work  to  care  for  the  children  and  house during  the  day,  had  to  quit  after  the  grandchild  of  her  teenage  child  was  born.  Frustration with  giving  up  her  plans  sums  up  to  the  disproportionate  care  work  placed  on  her  shoulders.  In  this  scenario,  an  app  that  doesn't  work  correctly  or  the  difficulty  of  scheduling  an appointment  for  any  family  member  also  increases  the  feeling  of  being  ' slowed  down ,' not  because  she  doesn't  want  to  solve  it  but  because  technology  sometimes  makes  it more  difficult,  as  she  explains.

Challenges  in  dealing  with  digital  social  services  seem  like  one  more  fight  in  a  life already  full  of  responsibilities  that  disproportionally  weigh  over  women.  On  the  other hand,  a  service  that  is  easy  to  access  is  considered  a  success.

' …  [a  digital  service  that  is  difficult  to  perform]  is  one  more  fight  for  your  day, for  your  life,  for  your  year ,…  the  facilitated  is  a  victory  …  because  during  our  life, especially  when  we  have  children,  our  responsibility  is  never  the  same  as  a  man's, never,  no  matter  how  much  the  man  does… '  (Camila)

Larissa's  experience  with  the  School  Kit  Duepay  is  a  good  illustration.  After  general critics  that  school  supplies  and  uniforms  delivered  by  the  city  hall  to  each  student  on the  first  day  of  classes  were  of  low  quality  and  concentrated  on  a  few  providers,  the municipal  government  decided  to  change  the  system  and  created  the  Duepay  app,  where families  now  receive  an  amount  of  money  and  can  freely  choose  the  shop  where  to  buy  it, as  well  as  choose  the  school  supplies  of  their  preference.  The  experience  was  acclaimed for  contributing  to  the  decentralization  of  public  expenditure,  benefiting  many  small entrepreneurs  throughout  the  city.  At  the  same  time,  citizens  were  given  more  autonomy

to choose  their supplies. Larissa recognizes  that the app is easy to use and that the materials  are  improved,  with  higher-quality  shirts  and  trousers,  but  she  would  prefer  the old  way,  as  she  now  has  even  more  work  to  do.

' On  the  one  hand,  it  is  good,  but  I  don't  see  a  difference  from  when  they  used to  give  the  material  at  school;  the  difference  now  …  they  gave  [me]  more  work because  many  times  when  you  can't  get  access,  you  have  to  be  like  calling  the school  to  try  to  find  out  why,  …  and  many  times  the  school  is  not  always  willing …  to  help  you '  (Larissa)

Some  of  the  women  mentioned  that  they  now  work  from  home,  utilizing  digital technologies  and  the  internet  to  learn  new  skills  and  start  new  businesses  in  pursuit  of autonomy  and  financial  prosperity.  While  this  opportunity  is  celebrated  by  them,  on  the other  hand,  it  also  emerges  as  a  way  to  reconcile  working  life  with  care  labor  and  rarely turns  into  free  time  for  themselves.

' After  the  pandemic,  we  found  it  very  good,  facilitated  …  to  stay  at  home,  to  have free  time,  but  after  a  while,  free  time  stops  being  your  free  time,  it  becomes  a  free time  of  the  home… '  (Camila)

## 4.4 Statement 4: An Evolving and Fragmented Experience

Between  feelings  of  anger  and  frustration  on  one  side  and  feelings  of  joy  and  care  on  the other,  the  use  of  services  over  the  years  implies  gaining  experience,  defining  preferences, and  watching  the  service  evolve.  Many  participants  reported  that  apps  developed  over the  years  have  become  better  designed  and  easier  to  navigate.  They  also  mentioned  apps that  they  prefer  over  others.  Helena,  for  instance,  described  her  lousy  experience  when she  created  an  account  at  Gov.br  and  the  sound  experience  of  accessing  it  recently.

' …  creating  an  account  [on  Gov.br]  was  very  bureaucratic,  wow,  it  took  too  long, the  confirmation  email  didn't  arrive,…  lasted  a  month  so  that  I  could  have  access… It  was  a  struggle,  a  horrible  experience  that  we  had…  But,  for  example,  today  I tried  [and]…  it  was  very  fast '  (Helena)

Inconsistencies  between  different  service  channels  do  not  go  unnoticed  by  participants  either.  Commenting  on  the  online  and  telephone  scheduling  (through  the  156 number,  the  city  hall  call  center)  of  CRAS  appointment,  Gabriela  notes:

' …  on  156,  you  never  get  it;  it's  easier  for  you  to  try  at  dawn  through  the  website so  you  find,  then  I  say:…  why  do  we  call  156  there  is  no  vacancy,  we  enter  at  night [in  the  website],  and  the  vacancies  appear,  at  dawn?' (Gabriela)

Among different  public  services  and  agencies,  the  lack  of  interoperability  and  varying paces of digitalization  combine  to  provide  fragmented  user  experiences.  Juliana,  for example,  attempted  to  renovate  her  special  unified  public  transportation  ticket  for  people with  disabilities  (Bilhete  Único)  but  needed  printed  proof  that  she  was  a  beneficiary  of  the BPC,  as  the  Transportation  office  wouldn't  accept  digital  evidence  despite  her  attempts. So,  she  went  to  an  INSS  agency,  where  she  discovered  that  this  kind  of  service  was  no

longer  available  offline  and  that  she  would  have  to  use  the  Meu  INSS  app  on  her  device and  have  a  4G  connection.  No  computers  or  totems  were  available  for  her  to  print  the document  at  the  INSS  agency.  After  accessing  the  app  and  downloading  the  document, she  had  to  look  for  a  Descomplica  unit  to  print  for  free.  After  printing  it,  she  had  to  hand in  the  paper  in  person  to  the  physical  agency  of  the  Transportation  office  to  have  her ticket  renovated.

When asked about what should be different, the way to improvement is also ambivalent,  pointing  to offline and digital solutions, as  exemplified  by  two  opposite speeches.

- ' What  had  to  be  different to be better?  Go  back  to  the old  days  …  go  back  to normally  serving  the  people,  get  in  line,  …  give  the  number  of  the  password  to people  to  get  to  the  attendant  …  This  is  what  would  be  best  for  the  elderly '  (Sofia).
- ' …  and  also  improve  the  online  customer  service…  because  sometimes  if  a  service, for  example,  from  Poupatempo,  goes  wrong,  you  have  excellent  online  customer  service, but  if  a  service  from  the  Digital  Work  Card  goes  wrong,  you  have  to  move  from  here  to the  city  center,  and  for  those  who  work,…  you  don't  have  time  to  go…  So,  when  they improve  the  digital  customer  service,  you  don't  need  to  have  this  commute,  nor  miss your  job  to  solve  it  either ,  or ,  for  example,  leave  the  outskirts,  cross  the  city  that  is  more than 15  km … '  (Camila).

## 5 Discussion

The  results  of  the  interpretative  phenomenological  analysis  (IPA)  highlighted  four  major group  experiential  statements  (GETs)  regarding  how  disadvantaged  women  from  the outskirts  of  Sªo  Paulo  experience  the  digitalization  of  social  policies  and  services,  with consequences  for  their  well-being.  GETs  are  summarized  in  Table  3.

Table 3. Summary  of  group  experiential  statements  (GETs)

|   Group experiential statements | Group experiential statements                            | Main aspects                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
|---------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|                               1 | Women found their way to digital social services somehow | Although women extensively access digital social services, neither the type of access nor connectivity can be considered meaningful and frequently demand solidarity networks or individual strategies to occur |
|                               2 | Ambivalent experiences shaped by identities              | Experiences within digital welfare are ambivalent even in a relatively homogeneous group of women, varying according to other aspects of identity                                                               |

( continued )

Table 3. ( continued )

| Group experiential statements                | Main aspects                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
|----------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 3. Reinforcement of gender roles and burdens | Whether digital services represent one more challenge in a life full of responsibilities or a victory and an opportunity that facilitates women's lives, they reinforce the gender roles associated with care work                                                                                                                                                        |
| 4. An evolving and fragmented experience     | The use of services over the years implies gaining experience and defining preferences, and most participants acknowledge the evolution of services. Inconsistencies between different service channels or a lack of interoperability among services do not go unnoticed, resulting in a fragmented experience. Envisioned futures to digital welfare are also ambivalent |

First,  as  no  other  alternative  was  left,  despite  financial,  educational,  and  other  constraints  that  some  of  the  participants  faced,  women  had  to  manage  access  to  digital  social services,  create  strategies  to  deal  with  limitations,  count  on  nets  of  solidarity  [23],  or  pay for  help  as  many  agencies  don't  have  face-to-face  service  anymore,  nor  totems  or  computers  that  can  be  used  with  the  assistance  of  a  public  agent.  However,  that  doesn't  mean meaningful  connectivity  [5]  in  terms  of  signal  quality  or  access  to  adequate  devices-a common  experience  that  all  participants  share,  one  way  or  another,  even  those  who  are better  off.

Some  of  the  interviewed  women  live  on  a  minimal  wage  per  month  (U$  260)  for the  whole  family,  and  internet  and  devices  have  become  an  obligation  they  must  afford, leaving  other  necessities  unattended.  Many  participants  reported  having  debts  they  could not  repay.  Women,  and  black/brown  women  in  particular,  usually  face  lower  levels  of salary  and  financial  deprivation,  and  digitalization  adds  one  more  monthly  cost.  While there  were  no  women  completely  excluded  from  services,  the  experiences  of  participants were  aligned  with  the  literature,  which  highlights  the  intersection  of  particular  contexts of  disadvantage  and  the  cost  of  complying  with  digital  services  [17].

Second,  in digital welfare, feelings of disrespect, anguish, humiliation, fear, and tiredness,  and  the  opposite,  feelings  of  being  a  citizen,  of  respect,  embracement,  and care,  are  all  present  as  intersectional  identities  such  as  age,  capabilities,  level  of  education,  family  configuration  among  others,  play  an  essential  role  in  the  experience.  This ambivalence  brings  at  least  two  implications.

Adding  to  previous  work  [3,  22,  25],  the  first  implication  is  that  the  design,  implementation,  and  evaluation  of  digital  services,  particularly  digital  social  services,  should account  for  the  experiences  of  real  people  in  their  contexts  as  unintended  or  unexpected consequences  and  perceptions  can  only  be  unveiled  in  the subjective experiences  of individuals.  As  stated  by  Almman  &amp;  Radu  [3,  p.  85],  we  need  to  look  into  the  ' mundane

rhythms of everyday life that the mechanisms  of  exclusion operate, only to  become wickedly  complex  patterns  of  marginalisation  at  scale '.

At  the  same  time,  another  implication  is  an  invitation  to  reflection  on  whether  digital exclusion  research,  added  by  the  literature  on  digital  welfare  [e.g.,  2,  11],  has  put  so  much emphasis  on  the  harming  consequences  of  digital  government  -  a  focus  that  is  extremely important  and  justified - that  a  look  into  the  good  consequences  that  live  together  with the bad ones, in  the  context  of  disadvantaged  citizens,  has  been  neglected.  Contrary to  what  the  evidence  in  the  literature  suggested,  some  of  the  disadvantaged  women  in this  research  also  demonstrated  satisfaction  and  embracement  in  their  experiences  with digital  welfare,  not  just  exclusion.  These  positive  experiences  cannot  be  attributed  solely to  young  age,  but  also  to  personal  preferences  and  individual  contexts,  as  in  the  case  of Mrs.  Valentina,  and  may  offer  insights  to  improve  practice.

Third,  women's  accounts  of  experiences  also  reveal  how  digital  welfare  is  deeply intertwined  with  the  cycle  of  life  and  the  experience  of  being  a  woman.  Retirement, loneliness,  motherhood,  affiliation,  and  paid  and  unpaid  work  are  essential  aspects  of  how women  experience  e-government,  shaping  meanings  and  feelings  within  digital  welfare. As  some  participants  perceive  digital  welfare  as  a  positive  experience  or  as  a  means to  fulfill  a  citizenship  ideal,  it  is  also  viewed  as  an  additional  complication,  increased responsibility,  and  a  reinforcement  of  traditional  gender  roles.  More  attention  should  be paid  to  how  life  situations  and  the  symbolic  and  concrete  aspects  of  women's  identities are  considered  in  the  design,  implementation,  and  evaluation  of  digital  services,  avoiding the  risk  of  engendering  gendered  administrative  burdens  [16]  and  moving  towards  an inclusive  vision  [24]  of  gender  in  digital  government.

Finally,  participants  acknowledged  gaining  experience  with  digital  technology  over the  years  and  recognized  the  evolution  of  digital  services,  underscoring  the  importance of  temporal  analysis  and  longitudinal  studies.  The  research  also  revealed  that  fragmentation  and  inconsistencies  are  not  overlooked,  indicating  that  women  perceive  digital welfare  as  a  system  comprising  both  digital  and  non-digital  processes  that  should  work in  harmony,  including  interoperability  among  different  services  and  levels  of  government,  both  vertically  and  horizontally.  If  experiences  are  ambivalent,  answers  to  digital welfare  challenges  cannot  be  unique.  Both  more  profound  levels  of  digitalization  and improved  offline  services  are  desired,  with  design  responsive  to  women's  struggles  and gender  burdens.  To  meet  the  diverse  needs  of  women,  easy  access  to  rights  in  all  forms, including  offline  formats,  emerges  as  the  future  of  digital  welfare  they  hope  for,  easing the  burdens  and  empowering  the  women  they  are.

## 6 Final Considerations

This  exploratory  and  inductive  research  demonstrated  that  disadvantaged  women  living in  the  M'Boi  Mirim  region,  out  of  necessity,  found  their  way  to  the  internet  and  digital welfare,  even if that  meant  relying  on neighbors,  family, volunteers, or paid helpers to  access  and  use  it.  However,  experiences  dealing  with  digital  welfare  are  ambivalent and influenced by various identity configurations, including age, level of education, capabilities,  family  structure,  personal  circumstances,  and  the  design  of  services.

From  the  theoretical  perspective,  the  study  helps  to  unveil  how  digital  social  services may,  at  the  same  time,  inflict  feelings  of  anxiety,  disablement,  fight,  and  exclusion,  as

also  feelings  of  inclusion,  embracement,  and  citizenship  that  add  to  their  offline  struggles related  to  intersectional  identities.

From  a  practical  perspective,  the  study  reveals  the  symbolic  and  concrete  meanings  and  consequences  of  digitalized  welfare  for  the  day-to-day  lives  of  disadvantaged women,  taking  into  account  their  differences  and  providing  insights  into  service  design, implementation,  evaluation,  and  improvement.  Suppose  services  are  to  reduce  injustice and  offer  opportunities  to  women  to  subvert  structures  that  diminish  their  ability  to  thrive; they  should  consider  women  not  as  a  unified  category  but  rather  as  individuals  living  in different  contexts.  Notably,  old  age,  reproductive  and  care  labor,  and  disabilities  should be  taken  into  consideration  from  the  demand  side.

The  study  has  limitations.  One  is  regarding  the  methodological  approach,  which doesn't  allow  for  generalization  and  thus  calls  for  more  research,  including  larger  samples  and  variation  of  methods.  Regarding  geography,  the  research  was  conducted  in an  urban  area  of  a  large  metropolis,  where  internet  infrastructure,  access  opportunities, and  educational  levels  tend  to  be  higher  than  in  other  regions  of  the  country  and  of  the Global  South.  Therefore,  different  contexts  might  offer  other  perspectives.  Additionally, the  study  focused  on  racialized  women  of  similar  social  class  and  gender  identities  from the  outset,  thereby  limiting  the  problematization  of  other  aspects  of  gender,  class,  and color/race,  which  are  central  to  intersectionality.  Gender  burdens  also  manifest  differently  in  various  parts  of  the  globe.  Still,  as  the  research  explores  women's  experiences in depth, the  reader can examine  and  judge  the  transferability  of  the results to other contexts  [19]  independently.

Future  studies  on  different  contexts,  focusing  on  the  intersectional  experiences  of women,  for  example,  delving  deeper  into  the  specificities  of  care  and  reproductive  work, would  contribute  to  elucidating  the  mechanisms  through  which  administrative  gender burdens  operate  in  digital  welfare  and  how  to  overcome  them.  However,  the  research also  shows  that  studies  on  the  positive  experiences  of  disadvantaged  women  and  the empowering  aspects  of  digital  welfare  are  required,  as  there  may  be  more  to  learn  from women  and  digital  welfare  than  just  accounts  of  exclusion.

## Online  Usability  and  Service  Standards in  the  Federal  Context:  A  Comparative  Analysis of  Australia  and  Canada

<!-- image -->

Morten  Meyerhoff  Nielsen ( B ) and  Luís  Nuno  Barbosa ( B )

<!-- image -->

United  Nations  University  Operating  Unit  on  Policy-Driven  Electronic  Governance (UNU-EGOV),  Guimarªes,  Portugal

{meyerhoff,nuno.barbosa}@unu.edu

Abstract. This  paper  develops  an  analytical  framework  based  on  the  usability principles  of  Jacob  Nielsen  and  Ben  Shneiderman  to  examine  how  federal  systems  approach  online  service  design  standards.  Focusing  on  Australia  and  Canada, the  paper  explores  the  interplay  between  federal  and  regional-level  design  standards  and  manuals,  highlighting  the  challenges  and  complementarities  in  achieving  consistency  across  government  levels.  Being  the  only  country  with  design standards  uniformly  applied  across  all  levels  of  government,  Denmark  is  referred to  in  the  analysis.  The  paper  finds  that  while  most  approaches  align  with  Nielsen's and  Shneiderman's  recommendations,  they  differ  in  their  implementation,  compliance  mechanisms,  and  inter-governmental  coordination.  The  paper  concludes with  a  set  of  policy  recommendations  for  federal  contexts.

Keywords: governance · service  design  standards · public  sector · online  service

## 1 Introduction

As  governments  increasingly  transition  service  delivery  to  digital  platforms  worldwide, the  need  for  coherent  and  user-centred  design  has  increasingly  become  a  critical  policy  concern.  Usability  plays  a  fundamental  role  in  digital  services,  as  poorly  designed services  frustrate  users  and  lead  to  higher  support  costs  and  reduced  user  adherence, leading  to  financial  inefficiencies  [1,  2].  Since  2012,  a  prominent  approach  to  offer  a structured tool to ensure a minimum  level  of usability  has  been  government  design standards  and  guides.  While  national  standards  have  existed  for  over  a  decade,  the  first regional-level  service  design  standards  began  to  appear  in  2019  in  federal countries, marking  a  relatively  recent  development  in  multi-level  digital  governance.

Federal  systems  add  a  layer  of  complexity  in  this  regard.  Users,  both  citizens  and businesses,  are  oftentimes  unfamiliar  with  the  division  of  responsibilities  between  federal, regional, and local levels of government.  Users have a reasonable expectation of  consistency  in  the  user  interface  across  the  public  sector,  leading  to  fragmented  and

Digital  Society  Track

'  IFIP  International  Federation  for  Information  Processing  2026

inconsistent  user  experiences.  Addressing  these  inconsistencies  often  requires  structured collaboration  across  levels  of  government.  This  paper  tries  to  understand  the  existence or  absence  of  such  collaboration  across  multi-level  systems.

As  part  of  a  broader  research  project  that  aims  to  map  the  different  approaches  to government  design  standards  and  respective  compliance  models,  this  paper  examines how  federal  systems  navigate  these  challenges,  focusing  on  Australia  and  Canada  as  case studies,  as  well  as  two  regional-level  governments  in  each  of  these  countries:  New  South Wales  and  South  Australia  for  the  first,  Alberta  and  Ontario  for  the  latter.  By  comparing these  systems,  the  paper  seeks  to  answer  a  central  question: How  do  governments  within federal  systems  ensure  a  minimum  level  of  usability  and  consistency  in  public  sector digital  services  across  multiple  levels  of  government? In  doing  so,  it  addresses  a  gap  in the  literature  on  how  user  experience  is  operationalised  to  be  consistent  across  multi-level governance  settings.

The  structure  of this paper  is as follows:  Section  2 provides  a  cursory  review  of online usability as  a  point  of  reference.  Section  3  presents  the  paper's  methodology, including  the  assessment  framework  developed  for  the  paper.  Section  4  analyses  the  two national  and  four  regional-level  governmental  approaches  to  online  usability.  Section  5 identifies how  governments  attempt  to improve  online usability with service design standards  and  what,  if any, is their  approach  to  tackling  consistency  across  different levels  of  government.  In  this  connection,  the  paper  draws  on  the  example  of  Denmark as  a  benchmark  case  for  its  unique  approach  of  fully  unified  design  standards  across all  levels  of  government.  Section  6  concludes  with  a  set  of  policy  recommendations on  what  may  be  considered  good  practices  for  usability  requirements  and  compliance mechanisms,  with  a  particular  focus  on  federal  contexts.

## 2 Online  Usability

Usability  has  been  a  significant  concern  in  digital  service  design  since  the  late  1990s.  A review  of  academic  literature  (using  Google  Scholar  and  ScienceDirect)  reveals  various research  strands  focused  on  usability  and  user-friendliness  in  online  services  and  website design.

Some  research  is concerned  with  accessibility and inclusive design, focusing  on making  web  content  accessible  to  all  users,  including  those  with  disabilities.  The  Web Content  Accessibility  Guidelines  (WCAG),  developed  by  the  W3C  [3,  4],  are  widely adopted,  with  many  governments  integrating  them  into  their  policies,  also  being  recommended  by  the  UN  in  relation  to  the  Convention  on  the  Rights  of  Persons  with  Disability. Similarly,  research  on  human-centred  design  and  usability  standards  emphasises  designing  systems  that  prioritise  user  needs  and  capabilities.  The  ISO  9241  series,  particularly Parts  110  and  210,  provide  comprehensive  guidelines  on  ergonomic  requirements  and human-centred  design  processes  [5,  6].

A  third  strand  of  research  focuses  on  User  Experience  (UX)  evaluation  and  measurement,  namely  in  assessing  user  satisfaction  and  the  overall  quality  of  web  interactions. Studies  have  explored  various  models  and  metrics  to  evaluate  UX,  such  as  the  Unified Theory  of  Acceptance  and  Use  of  Technology  (UTAUT)  model  [7-11],  which  examines factors  influencing  the  adoption  of  e-government  services;  or  design  thinking  [12,  13],

which  proposes  approaches  (i.e.  processes  and  tools)  to  ensure  that  end-users  are  engaged in  the  design,  development,  testing,  and  production  of  services.  While  these  standards and  approaches  are  internationally  recognised  and  serve  as  benchmarks  for  usability  in system  design,  none  address  language  use,  and  only  indirectly  common  look-and-feel, functionality,  or  reuse  of  components  or  compliance  with  other  standards  or  legislation, e.g.,  privacy  and  data  protection.

Another  research  strand  emphasises  the  importance  of  cultural  and  contextual  factors  in  usability  and  how  they  impact  user  interaction  with  websites  and  online  services [14,  15].  This  strand  investigates  how  cultural  dimensions  influence  usability  perceptions,  including  language  [16],  colours,  aesthetics  [17],  and  their  impact  on  the  level  of perceived  satisfaction  [15].  Research  has  led  to  the  development  of  culturally-oriented usability  evaluation  tools  to  better  cater  to  diverse  user  groups  [17,  18].

Among these,  design  thinking  uniquely  combines  accessibility,  perceived  ease  of  use, and  the  needs  of  individual  users  and  target  communities  [13,  19].  It  offers  a  practical, user-centred  framework  that  encourages  iterative  development  with  the  active  involvement  of  stakeholders.  However,  despite  these  strengths,  it  is  generally  applied  within  the context  of  single  solutions  or  organisations.

Unlike other research strands, design thinking is anchored  in research by Jacob Nielsen  [20]  and  Ben  Shneiderman  [21],  who  have  established  principles  that  continue to  influence  online  design  decisions.  Based  on  actual  user  behaviour,  Nielsen's  Designing Web  Usability  [20]  proposes  ten  principles,  or  heuristics,  to  increase  user-friendliness, focusing  on  a  simple  yet  consistent  experience.  One  key  feature  of  Nielsen's  principles  is that  he  sees  online  behaviour  as  universal,  not  influenced  by  any  social  or  demographic characteristics  of  the  user,  while  acknowledging  exceptions,  such  as  reading  patterns or different levels of IT skills. His heuristics are designed  to be broadly  applicable, considering  the  uniformity  in  how  users  interact  with  digital  systems.

By  comparison,  Shneiderman's Universal  Usability [21]  takes  a  more  nuanced  approach.  He  acknowledges  that  knowledge,  skills,  age,  gender,  socio-economic  status,  or cultural  differences  can  affect  online  behaviour  as  these  also  affect  user's  needs.  He  also sees  technology  and  hardware  as  relevant  in  shaping  user  experiences.  These  concerns are  visible  in  his  heuristics,  for  example,  suggesting  that  one  should  design  with  different skill  levels  in  mind,  giving  support  for  less  savvy  and  shortcuts  for  expert  users,  but  also that  interfaces  should  be  tailored  to  specific  user  tasks  and  preferences.

Beyond  Nielsen  and  Shneiderman,  much  of  the  usability  research  tends  to  emphasise  its  importance  for  value  creation,  such  as  return  on  investment  and  digital  inclusion, rather  than  proposing  concrete  solutions,  assessment  frameworks,  or  monitoring  mechanisms  on  the  actual  design  of  services.  From  the  2020s,  the  focus  has  mainly  been  on service  quality,  user-friendliness,  or  usability  [22-28],  which  in  turn  tend  to  be  linked to  trust  [29],  satisfaction,  and  loyalty  [24,  30,  31].  Other  topics  include  accessibility  for specific  groups,  such  as  the  visually  impaired  [32]  and  the  role  of  technology  in  enhancing  usability  [26,  33].  The  service  quality  literature  generally  examines  conceptual  elements  such  as  reliability/fulfilment,  responsiveness,  web  design,  ease  of  use/usability, privacy/security,  and  information  quality/benefit  [23,  24,  28,  32,  34].  These  elements, however,  remain  broad  conceptual  outcomes.  While  these  elements  could  form  the  basis of  assessment  criteria - for  example,  through  Likert  scales - this  is  rarely  attempted.

Adding  to  that,  key  international  and  regional  ICT-related  databases  and  benchmarks like  those  managed  by  the  ITU,  UNDESA,  World  Bank,  or  the  EU  do  not  measure service  use  or  usability  [35-39].

Early  attempts  to  establish  public  sector  principles  and  standards  include  the  Canadian  Common  Look  and  Feel  Standard  for  the  Internet  in  2000  [40],  the  Norwegian ELMER  in  2006  [41],  and  the  UK's  Guide  to  good  practice  in  commissioning  accessible  websites  in  2006  [42]  and  Web  accessibility  Code  of  Practice  in  2010  [43].  The 2012  launch  of  the  UK's  Digital  Service  Standards  [44,  45]  marked  a  turning  point  in the  relevance  given  to  usability  within  both  policy  circles  and  the  public  sector  [46,  47]. Since  then,  design  standards  have  gained  prominence  globally,  with  16  countries  across all  continents  publishing  national  standards  and/or  guidelines  [47].  Together  with  them, governance  and  compliance  models  have  emerged  as  critical  tools  for  ensuring  adherence  to  the  criteria  outlined  in  the  design  standards  [48-51].  Poor  usability  is,  indeed,  a major  barrier  to  the  adoption  of  digital  services,  which  limits  the  realisation  of  cost  and efficiency  gains  brought  by  digital  government.

While  often  aligned  wholly  or  partially  with  Nielsen  and  Shneiderman's  proposed criteria,  the  standards  and  their  governance  and  compliance  models  vary  in  detail  and scope.  At  the  same  time,  there  still  seems  to  be  a  trial-and-error  method  to  finding  the best  solutions,  as  is  suggested  by  the  findings  of  a  comparative  study  of  Denmark,  the UK,  and  Portugal  [52]  and  its  updates  over  time.

In  this  context,  this  paper  sheds  some  light  on  the  following  questions.  First, which principles  are  covered  by  design  standards  to  advance  online  service  usability? Second, which,  if  any,  governance  models  are  applied  to  report,  assess,  and  ensure  compliance? Third, which,  if  any,  are  the  strategies  used  to  ensure  consistency  in  service  delivery across  different  levels  of  government?

## 3 Methodology

To assess and compare  in a fair manner  the various approaches  to usability criteria from  different  countries,  the  recommendations  of  Nielsen  [20]  and  Shneiderman  [21] form  the  theoretical  basis  of  the  methodology  followed.  A  meta-synthesis  of  the  key recommendations  of  both  authors  is  developed  and  organised  around  overarching  categories  to  measure  each  country's  design  standards.  This  way,  an  assessment  framework that  adequately  serves  as  a  lens  for  evaluating  the  various  design  standards  is  reached 1 . By  grounding  the  assessment  in  established  usability  heuristics,  this  paper  enables  a more  granular  and  design-focused  comparison  that  can  complement  and  inform  maturity models  in  future  research.

Along  with  the  theoretical  recommendations  for  standards  that  primarily  focus  on what  a  website  should  achieve,  even  when  there  are  some  underlying  processes,  the assessment  framework  intentionally  includes  categories  that  are  more  connected  to  processes  (how  to  get  there).  Thus,  the  assessment  framework  includes  elements  like  toolkits, stylesheets,  practical  examples,  minimum  acceptance  criteria,  and  the  call  to  monitor use  and  usability  and  perform  user  testing.

1 This  framework  is  developed  as  part  of  a  broader  ongoing  research  project  aimed  at  developing a  comprehensive  approach  to  assess  and  compare  digital  government  design  standards.

Each  country's design standards are evaluated across 15 overarching categories, each comprising  varying criteria, on a 0-2 scale, where  zero (0) signifies either no or barely any reference  to the criterion, one (1) indicates that a criterion is partially covered, and two (2) denotes that a criterion is fully or close to fully covered. The 15  overarching  categories  are  'development  process',  'language  use',  'look-and-feel', 'functionality',  'reuse  of  components',  'reuse  of  standards',  'reuse  of  data',  'device independence',  'WCAG  Accessibility  standards',  'monitoring  of  use  and  usability', 'minimum  acceptance  criteria',  'user  testing',  'examples',  'toolkit',  and  'stylesheet'. Table  1  maps  the  process  from  the  theoretical  basis  to  the  final  assessment  framework.

For  each  country,  an  analysis  examines  how  this  information  is  presented,  the  coverage  of  the  standards,  i.e.,  to  which  institutions  and  organisations  it  applies,  and  whether its  adoption  is  voluntary  or  mandatory.  Finally,  the  mechanisms  to  report,  assess,  and ensure  compliance  are  also  analysed.  All  assessments  reflect  the  state  of  the  documents  as of  31  December  2024.  This  cut-off  date  ensures  comparability  across  cases  and  provides a  fixed  point  of  reference  for  analysis.

The  goal  is  to  uncover  insights  related  to  the  research  questions  through  an  analytical comparison.  In  addition  to  the  design  standards  and  associated  guidelines,  strategy  documents  such  as  policy  papers,  policy  recommendations,  digital  government  strategies, action  plans,  and  management  reports  are  analysed  where  relevant.  National  portals  are examined  to  assess  the  impact  of  the  design  standards  and  usability  guidelines  based  on the  premise  that  non-compliant  portals  suggest  other  authority  websites  and  eServices are  likely  non-compliant.

The  first  step  is  exploratory,  aiming  to  understand  how  the  information  is  organised  in each  country's  standards.  Then,  for  each  criterion,  the  most  relevant  quotes  are  collected as  evidence  of  its  coverage.  Afterwards,  each  criterion  is  assessed  throughout  the  different countries  for  increased  objectivity.  For  those  that  are  not  fully  compliant,  new  searches are  conducted  in  the  guidelines  and  associated  documents  using  keywords  used  by  the more  compliant  countries  to  make  sure  no  information  is  missed.  After  this,  a  second person  reviews  the  assessment,  basing  it  on  the  relevant  quotes,  with  any  differences being  thoroughly  discussed  and  compared  to  the  other  countries'  assessments.

The comparative design facilitates uncovering patterns and divergences in approaches  to  usability  standards  and  respective  governance  models  within  and  between federated  systems.  In  future  research,  this  analysis  could  be  expanded  with  interviews.

Globally,  16  countries  have  published  design  standards  or  similar  [47].  Although several  of  these  countries  have  a  federal  structure  (such  as  Mexico,  India,  or  the  USA), this  paper  focuses  on  the  cases  of  Australia  and  Canada  as  they  are  the  only  two  federal countries with published  design standards at both national (i.e.  federal  government) and regional levels (i.e. state or provincial government),  which  are  the  basis for the case  selection.  For  each,  two  state  or  provincial  approaches  were  chosen.  In  Canada, only  Alberta  and  Ontario  have  published  design  standards.  In  Australia,  Victoria  [53], New  South  Wales  [54],  South  Australia  [55],  and  Queensland  [56]  have  either  design standards  or  design  systems  in  place.  New  South  Wales  and  South  Australia  were  chosen for  having  publicly  available  standards  and  design  systems  and  different  approaches  to implementation.  Denmark  serves  as  a  complementary  reference  case,  as  it  is  the  only

country  where  the  standards  are  developed  and  apply  equally  to  all  levels  of  government [47,  52],  which  could  offer  insights  into  cross-governmental  consistency.

## 4 Approaches  to  Design  Standards,  and  Governance and  Compliance  Models

With  a  focus  on  Australia  and  Canada,  both  at  the  federal  and  the  regional  levels,  namely the  states  of  New  South  Wales  and  South  Australia  and  the  provinces  of  Alberta  and Ontario,  this  section  outlines  their  approaches  to  usability  criteria  and  governance  and compliance  models,  also  trying  to  draw  upon  any  communication  between  different levels  of  government.

For each case, the first section analyses the approach to usability, describing how  information  is  presented,  which  entity  or  entities  are  responsible,  any  tools  and guidelines,  and  further  evaluation  within  the  assessment  framework.

This  is  followed  by  a  second  section  identifying  each  country's  governance  and  compliance  model,  including  who  must  comply,  who  is  responsible  for  assessing,  reporting and  monitoring  compliance,  and  what  processes  apply  to  ensure  it.

## 4.1 Australia

## Federal

Approach  to  Usability

The  Australian Digital Service Standard  [57] was  launched  in its current version in December  2023  and  last  updated  in  October  2024.  It  defines  the  criteria  under  which government  services should be developed and designed. The first version, 1.0, was launched  in  2015.  The  Digital  Transformation  Agency  (DTA)  is  the  authority  responsible for  these  service  standards.

The  standards  comprises  ten  criteria,  each  of  them  having  a  brief  explanation,  followed  by  the  responsibilities  of  those  who  develop  to  meet  each  specific  criterion,  the development  phase  in  which  that  criterion  should  be  mainly  observed,  a  set  of  questions to  consider,  and  a  list  of  suggested  activities  to  apply  the  criterion.  Finally,  it  presents  a list  of  tools  and  resources  that  can  be  used  to  learn  more  about  each  topic.

The  Digital  Service  Standard  is  included  in  a  broader  toolkit  comprising  information and  resources  on  ICT  investment,  transitioning  from  the  previous  to  the  current  version of  the  standards,  user  research,  and  teams'  management,  among  others.  A  set  of  relevant communities  of  practice  for  government  specialists,  practitioners,  and  leaders  to  share experiences  is  also  provided,  as  well  as  the  Australian  Government  Style  Manual  [58] and  the  GOLD  Design  System  [59].

When  assessed  against the paper's assessment  framework,  it covers most of the overarching categories, namely  the development  process, functionality, the reuse of components,  standards,  and  data,  device  independence,  the  WCAG  accessibility  criteria, the  need  for  monitoring  of  use  and  usability,  as  well  as  having  minimum  acceptance criteria.  It  partially  covers  language  use,  look-and-feel,  and  the  need  for  user  testing.

According  to  the  responsible  authority,  version  2.0  reduced  the  criteria  from  13  to ten,  improving  the  accessibility  and  inclusion  requirements  and  introducing  new  ones for  staff-facing  services.

## Governance  and  Compliance  Model

The  standards  apply  to  all  informational,  transactional,  and  staff-facing  services  by  the federal  government  and  its  entities  (the  so-called  NCCE  -  non-corporate  Commonwealth entities).  While  public-facing  informational  and  transactional  services  must  adhere  to the  standards,  regardless  of  whether  they  are  pre-existing  or  new,  staff-facing  services only  have  to  meet  the  standards  if  they  are  new.  State,  territory,  or  local  government services  are  not  required  to  follow  the  standards,  but  they  may  choose  to  if  they  want  'to improve  access  and  discoverability  of  their  digital  services'  [60].  Personal  ministerial websites  are  also  not  required  to  follow  the  principles.

While  applying  the  standards  is  mandatory,  federal  agencies  may  request  a  partial or complete  exemption  if  justified by the existence of legacy technology  barriers or disproportionate  financial  burden.

DTA  is  responsible  for  monitoring  websites  based  on  self-reported  compliance.  This monitoring  was  set  to  start  for  new  services  in  July  2024  and  for  existing  public-facing services  in  July  2025.  However,  the  mechanism  was  not  published  apart  from  a  note saying  DTA  would  engage  with  stakeholders  and  develop  a  reporting  framework  before the  requirements  were  put  in  place,  leading  to  the  belief  that  it  was  behind  schedule.

DTA  also  outlines  the  process  to  get  approval  for  ICT  Investments,  which  is  key  for big  projects.  For  this,  a  proposal  must  be  submitted  following  the  principles  outlined  in the  Standards,  for  DTA  to  assess.

## New  South  Wales

Approach  to  Usability

The  Australian  state  of  New  South  Wales  has  established  its  own  Design  Standards.  It is  integrated  into  a  more  extensive  set  of  tools  called  the  Digital  Service  Toolkit  [54].  It was  launched  in  May  2022  and  last  updated  in  July  2022.

The  Design  Standards  are  composed  of  ten  rules,  presented  with  a  brief  explanation and  a  set  of  implementation  measures  in  bullet  points  that  make  each  rule  more  tangible. These  standards  are  integrated  into  the  aforementioned  toolkit,  which  also  includes  a design  system,  resources  for  user  research,  user  experience  and  design,  content  writing,  testing,  and  collaboration  tools.  It  also  includes  templates  and  solutions  previously developed  that  any  agency  can  use.  Examples,  however,  are  rarely,  if  at  all,  provided.

With  respect  to  the  paper's  assessment  framework,  the  Design  Standards  include information  about  the  development  process,  the  reuse  of  components,  relevant  standards and  data,  the  WCAG  accessibility  standards,  minimum  acceptance  criteria,  and  the  need for  user  testing.  It  partially  covers  language  use  and  the  need  to  monitor  use  and  usability. There  is  either  no  or  only  scarce  reference  to  look-and-feel,  functionality,  and  device independence.

Across  the  toolkit,  there  is  minimal  reference  to  federal  documents  or  standards, except  for  very  specific  topics,  such  as  cybersecurity.  However,  it  is  interesting  to  note that  the  'Credits'  section  on  the  Delivery  Manual  specifies  that  these  resources  are  built upon  three  guides:  the  GOV .UK  service  manual,  international  standards  and  the  first that  appeared,  the  Australian  Service  Design  (federal),  and  Ontario  Public  Service,  the manual  of  another  region  in  a  different  federal  setting.  The  steps  for  development  in New  South  Wales  are  an  expansion  of  the  ones  in  the  Federal  standards.

## Governance  and  Compliance  Model

The  design  standards,  the  design  system,  and  all  the  related  components  are  voluntary for  all  parties.  The  design  standards  are  maintained  by  Digital  NSW,  which  is  an  integral part  of  the  regional  state-level  government.  All  state-level  agencies  and  departments  that use  the  design  standards  are  encouraged  to  establish  metrics,  collect  data,  and  conduct an  iterative  process  of  monitoring  and  improving.  However,  this  is  a  self-assessment method,  and  no  formal  compliance  model  is  in  place.

## South  Australia

Approach  to  usability

The  Online  Accessibility  Toolkit  [55]  was  developed  by  the  Government  of  South  Australia.  The  government  approved  the  Online  Accessibility  Policy  in  May  2019,  derived from  the  federal  Digital  Service  Standard.  It  was  last  updated  in  June  2021.

The  Online  Accessibility  Toolkit  is  organised  as  a  set  of  different  guides  for  specific tasks. Each has a separate page explaining why  it is important, followed by a task description.  It  then  goes  on  to  describe  the  Steps  to  Take,  often  with  several  links  to helpful tools. Sometimes,  there  is  a short video  on  the topic and  a set  of  supporting resources.  It  focuses  more  on  accessibility  and  frames  most  topics  within  that  scope.  It often  refers  to  the  national  standards,  including  in  the  service  design  section,  where  it points  to  the  adoption  of  the  national  process  manual.

With  respect  to  the  paper's  assessment  framework,  the  toolkit  references  to  the  reuse of  components  and  standards,  device  independence,  the  WCAG  accessibility  criteria, and  the  need  for  user  testing.  It  partially  covers  the  development  process,  language  use, look-and-feel,  and  functionality.  There  is  no  reference  to  the  reuse  of  data  nor  the  need for  monitoring  use  and  usability.  There  are  also  no  minimum  acceptance  criteria.  It  also has  a  toolkit  that  adds  important  information,  such  as  a  Website  Design  System  and  an Online  Forms  Platform.  It  also  adopts  the  Federal  style  manual.

## Governance  and  Compliance  Model

According  to  state-level  policy,  the  toolkit  must  be  applied  to  every  South  Australian government  online  application,  including  public  and  staff-facing  applications.

Although  it is mandatory  to comply  with  the Toolkit standards, there is no formal  screening  process,  making  compliance  with  the  criteria  reliant  on  trust  and  selfassessment.  However,  any  vendor  contracted  regarding  ICT  development  must  prove they  will  comply  with  the  accessibility  criteria.

## 4.2 Canada

## Federal

Approach  to  Usability

The  Designing  for  Canada.ca  [61]  website  was  launched  by  the  Federal  Canadian  government  in July 2017  and  contains  a set of standards  and  a toolkit.  The  responsible agency  is  the  Digital  Transformation  Office  (DTO),  which  is  part  of  Employment  and Social  Development  Canada.  The  toolkit  expands  and  complements  the  existing  Web Experience  Toolkit  [62]  (in  place  since  at  least  2012).  The  standards  and  toolkit  are  managed  by  the  Treasury  Board  of  Canada  Secretariat,  but  its  development  and  maintenance involve  a  collaborative  process.

The  standards  include  a  set  of  guidelines  and  tools.  Most  of  them  are  organised  first with  the  most  recent  updates  made,  followed  by  the  purpose  of  that  guide  or  tool,  how to  use  it,  and  a  set  of  related  policies,  standards,  and  procedures,  after  which  follows  its actual  content.

With  respect  to  the  paper's  assessment  framework,  the  Canadian  Digital  Service  is clear  about  language  use,  reuse  of  components  and  data,  device  independence,  WCAG accessibility  criteria,  monitoring  of  use  and  usability,  and  user  testing.  It  partially  covers the  development  process,  look-and-feel,  functionality,  and  the  reuse  of  standards.  It  also partially covers the need for minimum  acceptance  criteria.  It  is  complemented  by  a Style  Guide  [63],  a  Design  System  [64],  and  the  previously  mentioned  Web  Experience Toolkit.

## Governance  and  Compliance  Model

Application  of  the  'Canada.ca  Content  and  Information  Architecture  Specification'  (the Canada.ca  design)  is  mandatory  for  'departments  and  other  portions  of  the  federal  public administration'.  All  149  institutions  that  must  comply  are  listed.  It  is  also  mandatory to  adhere  to  the  Standard  on  Web  Accessibility,  the  Standard  on  Web  Usability,  and  the Standard  on  Web  Interoperability.  The  Web  Experience  Toolkit  is  optional  but  recommended,  as  it  helps  agencies  to  comply  with  these  standards.  Territory  and  province governments  (i.e.,  regional  level)  are  neither  acknowledged  nor  mentioned  within  the standards  or  associated  toolkits.

It  is  clear  which  parts  of  the  extensive  guidelines  and  tools  are  mandatory  and  which are  voluntary.  However,  there  is  no  mention  of  any  mechanisms  to  ensure  compliance. The  departments  and  agencies  responsible  for  government  websites  and  eServices  are urged  to  continuously  improve  usability  by  monitoring  and  measuring  task  success.  This is  based  on  a  recommended  self-assessment  procedure.

All  departments  and  agencies  subject  to  the  Directive  on  the  Management  of  Communications  must  implement  the  GC  Task  Success  Survey  on  their  web  properties  and report  its  results  to  the  Government  of  Canada.  There  is,  however,  no  screening  process detailed  starting  from  there.

## Alberta

## Approach  to  Usability

Alberta's  Digital  Experience  Standard  [65]  is  managed  by  the  Government  of  Alberta. Although  there  is  no  mention  of  the  date  it  was  created  or  its  last  update,  using  the  Wayback  Machine  [66],  it  was  possible  to  find  it  was  first  referenced  in  August  2023,  and  its last  recorded  update  is  from  July  2024.  The  responsible  authority  is  the  Communications and  Public  Engagement  Ministry.

The  standards  and  associated  tools  comprise  a  checklist  to  ensure  compliance,  a  set  of code  elements,  and  a  design  system.  This  is  complemented  with  a  set  of  content  guides. The  standards  are  mandatory  for  every  public-facing  website  or  application  owned  and operated  by  the  Government  of  Alberta  and  its  agencies.  There  is  no  mention  of  the federal  or  national  level  service  provision  or  design  guide,  suggesting  there  is  no  formal coordination  and  collaboration  between  the  federal  and  provincial  levels.

With  respect  to  the  paper's  assessment  framework,  the  standards  are  thorough  about language  use,  reuse  of  components,  and  device  independence.  They  partially  cover  the development  process,  look-and-feel,  functionality,  reuse  of  standards,  WCAG  accessibility  criteria,  and  the  need  for  user  testing.  They  do  not  cover  reuse  of  data  and  the  need to  monitor  use  and  usability.  They  includes  minimum  acceptance  criteria,  examples,  a toolkit,  and  a  stylesheet.

## Governance  and  Compliance  Model

The  standards  are  mandatory  for  all  public-facing  websites  and  applications  owned  and operated  by  the  Government  of  Alberta.

The  web  governance  team  at  the  Ministry  of  Communications  &amp;  Public  Engagement monitors  the  process.  First,  project  owners  are  invited  to  review  the  standards  and  make sure  what  they  want  to  build  is  compliant,  after  which  they  are  prompted  to  contact  the web  governance  team,  who  should  assess  to  what  point  it  can  be  integrated  with  the government  portal  or  other  Government  of  Alberta's  websites.  Some  contents  might  be directly  built  into  the  government's  portal  to  avoid  duplication.  After  this,  they  should contact the  communications  team  from  the  ministry  to  which  the  project  belongs  to analyse interactions and communication  timelines.  Lastly,  the team  can develop  the website  or application  in line with the  standards'  requirements.  The  last  two  to  four weeks  before  launch  are  designated  for  a  pre-launch  review  by  the  web  governance team,  which  will  make  sure  it  is  compliant  and  can  be  published.

## Ontario

## Approach  to  Usability

Ontario's  Digital  Service  Standard  [67]  is  managed  by  the  Government  of  Ontario  to assist  provincial  agencies  and  ministries  in  building  and  delivering  simpler,  faster,  and better  government  services  and  products.  It  was  first  published  in  January  2021  and  last updated  in  October  2024.

The  standards  include  a  description  of  the  development  process,  including  the  phases of  publishing  and  13  principles  considered  essential  to  good  service  delivery.  Each  has  a short  explanation  of  what  it  is,  a  section  on  why  it  matters,  and  a  final  one  on  how  to  meet it.  In  this  final  section,  the  information  is  organised  by  minimum  requirements  and  what to  consider  in  each  development  phase.  Lastly,  when  applicable,  there  is  a  section  on laws  and  rules  to  follow  within  the  scope  of  that  principle.  The  standards  and  associated manual  acknowledge  their  inspiration  in  several  other  standards,  including  the  Canadian national  one,  as  well  as  Australia,  the  UK  and  the  USA.

The  standards  are  complemented  by  the  Ontario  Design  System  [68],  which  includes a  stylesheet,  components  that  can  be  reused,  and  examples.

With  respect  to  the  assessment  framework,  these  standards  cover  the  development process,  reuse  of  components,  standards,  and  data,  device  independence,  WCAG  accessibility  criteria,  the  need  for  monitoring  of  use  and  usability,  and  user  testing.  They  also partially  cover  language  use,  look-and-feel,  and  functionality.

## Governance  and  Compliance  Model

The  standards  and  associated  manual  are  produced  for  all  ministries  and  agencies  of the  Government  of  Ontario.  However,  compliance  is  voluntary,  based  on  decentralised responsibility,  with  no  formal  or  mandatory  screening  process  in  place.

## 5 Analysis

Having presented the two federal and four regional-level (i.e. six individual cases) approaches  to  design  standards  for  service  delivery, which  principles  are  covered  by design  standards  to  advance  online  service  usability?

Table  2  maps  the  six  approaches  utilising  the  paper's  assessment  framework.  The mapping  applies  the  0-2  scale  outlined  in  the  methodology.

The  analysis  finds that  all  six  cases  have  incorporated  the  overarching  principles in  the  framework.  This  confirms  the  impact  and  continued  relevance  of  Nielsen's  and Shneiderman's  work.  It  is  worth  noting  that both federal governments  cover  at  least partially  every  overarching  category,  while  three  of  the  regional-level  standards  fail  to include  at  least  a  couple  of  topics,  with  Ontario  being  the  exception.

With  respect  to which,  if  any,  governance  models  are  applied  to  report,  assess, and  ensure  compliance? ,  the  analysis  finds  that  both  coverage  and  approaches  vary significantly.  The  Australian  and  the  Canadian  federal  governments,  as  well  as  South Australia,  make  compliance  mandatory,  but  have  no  formal  mechanism  to  ensure  it.  The Australian  federal  government  makes  larger  ICT  investments  subject  to  approval  by  the same  agency  that  oversees  the  standards  but  does  not  have  an  associated  compliance mechanism.  In  this case, full or partial exemptions  can  be  granted  upon  request  for authorities  that  cannot  comply,  for  example,  because  of  legacy  technology  or  excessive financial  burden.

The  Australian  federal government  was  set  to publish  a  self-reporting  and  monitoring mechanism  but  is  yet to do so. In South  Australia,  vendors  must  promise  to comply  and  prove  the  ability  to  do  so  prior  to  the  contract,  but  no  screening  or  reporting mechanisms  are  in  place.  By  comparison,  the  Canadian  federal  government  encourages
